<article_start> </s> guatemala ( ; ) , officially the republic of guatemala ( repblica de guatemala links=no ) , is a country in central america bordered by mexico to the north and west , belize and the caribbean sea to the northeast , honduras to the east , el salvador to the southeast and the pacific ocean to the south . with an estimated population of around million , it is the most populous country in central america and ha the <number> largest national population in the america . guatemala is a representative democracy ; it capital and largest city is nueva guatemala de la asuncin , also known a guatemala city . </s> the core of the maya civilization , which extended across mesoamerica , wa historically based in the territory of modern guatemala . in the <number> century , most of this area wa spanish conquest of guatemala and claimed a part of the viceroyalty of new spain . guatemala attained independence in <year> a part of the federal republic of central america , which dissolved by <year> . </s> from the mid- to late <number> century , guatemala suffered chronic instability and civil strife . beginning in the early <number> century , it wa ruled by a series of dictator backed by the united fruit company and the united state federal government of the united state . in <year> , the authoritarian leader jorge ubico wa overthrown by a pro-democratic military coup , initiating a guatemalan revolution decade-long revolution that led to sweeping social and economic reform . a <year> guatemalan coup d'tat u.s.-backed military coup in <year> ended the revolution and installed a dictatorship . </s> from <year> to <year> , guatemala guatemalan civil war fought between the us-backed government and left-wing politics rebel , including guatemalan genocide of the maya population perpetrated by the military . since a united nations-negotiated peace accord , guatemala ha achieved both economic growth and successful democratic election , although it continues to struggle with high rate of poverty and crime , drug cartel , and instability . , guatemala rank <number> of <number> latin american and caribbean country in term of the human development index . </s> guatemala 's abundance of biologically significant and unique ecosystem includes many endemic specie and contributes to mesoamerica 's designation a a biodiversity hotspot . </s> <section_title_start> etymology <section_title_end> </s> the name `` guatemala `` come from the nahuatl language word cuauhtmalln : nah : cuauhtmalln ( nahwiki ) , or `` place of many tree `` , a derivative of the k'iche ' people k'iche ' mayan word for `` many tree `` or , perhaps more specifically , for the cuate/cuatli tree eysenhardtia . this wa the name that the tlaxcala warrior who accompanied pedro de alvarado during the spanish conquest gave to this territory . </s> <section_title_start> history <section_title_end> </s> <section_title_start> pre-columbian <section_title_end> </s> the first evidence of human habitation in guatemala date to <number> bc . archeological evidence , such a obsidian arrowhead found in various part of the country , suggests a human presence a early a <number> bc . there is archaeological proof that early guatemalan settler were [ pollen sample from petn basin petn ] and the pacific coast indicate that [ [ maize cultivation had been developed by the people by <year> bc . site dating to <year> bc have been found in the quich department region in the highland , and sipacate and escuintla on the central pacific coast . </s> archaeologist divide the pre-columbian era pre-columbian history of mesoamerica into the preclassic period ( <year> bc to <number> ad ) , the classic period ( <number> to <number> ad ) , and the postclassic period ( <number> to <year> ad ) . until recently , the preclassic wa regarded by researcher a a formative period , in which the people typically lived in hut in small village of farmer , with few permanent building . </s> this notion ha been challenged since the late <number> century by discovery of monumental architecture from that period , such a an altar in la blanca , san marcos department , from <year> bc ; ceremonial site at miraflores and naranjo from <number> bc ; the earliest monumental mask ; and the mirador basin city of nakb , xulnal , el tintal , wakn and el mirador . </s> on <number> june <year> , researcher published an article in nature ( journal ) describing their discovery of the oldest and largest maya site , known a aguada fnix , in mexico . it feature monumental architecture , an elevated , rectangular plateau measuring about <number> meter long and nearly <number> meter wide , constructed of a mixture of earth and clay . to the west is a <number>-meter-tall earthen mound . remains of other structure and reservoir were also detected through the lidar technology . it is estimated to have been built from <year> to <number> bc , demonstrating that the maya built large , monumental complex from their early period . </s> the classic period of mesoamerican civilization corresponds to the height of the maya civilization . it is represented by countless site throughout guatemala , although the largest concentration is in petn basin . this period is characterized by urbanisation , the emergence of independent city-state , and contact with other mesoamerican culture . </s> this lasted until approximately <number> ad , when the classic maya collapse . the maya abandoned many of the city of the central lowland or were killed by a drought-induced famine . the cause of the collapse is debated , but the drought theory is gaining currency , supported by evidence such a lakebeds , ancient pollen , and others . a series of prolonged drought in what is otherwise a seasonal desert is thought to have decimated the maya , who relied on regular rainfall to support their dense population . </s> the post-classic period is represented by regional kingdom , such a the itza people , kowoj , yalain and kejache in petn , and the mam people , k'iche ' people ki'che ' , kaqchikel people , chajoma , tz'utujil people tz'utujil , poqomchi ' people poqomchi ' , q'eqchi ' people q'eqchi ' and ch'orti ' people ch'orti ' people in the highland . their city preserved many aspect of maya culture . </s> the maya civilization share many feature with other mesoamerican civilization due to the high degree of interaction and cultural diffusion that characterized the region . advance such a writing , epigraphy , and the maya calendar did not originate with the maya ; however , their civilization fully developed them . maya influence can be detected from honduras , guatemala , and northern el salvador to a far north a central mexico , more than from the geography of mesoamerica # maya region . many outside influence are found in maya art and architecture , which are thought to have resulted from trade and cultural exchange rather than direct external conquest . </s> <section_title_start> archaeological investigation <section_title_end> </s> in <year> , <number> uncharted structure were revealed in northern guatemala by archaeologist with the help of lidar technology laser . the project applied lidar technology on an area of <number> square kilometer in the maya biosphere reserve in the petn department region of guatemala . thanks to the new finding , archaeologist believe that <number> million maya people inhabited northern guatemala during the late classical period from <number> to <number> a.d. , twice the estimated population of medieval england . lidar technology digitally removed the tree canopy to reveal ancient remains and showed that maya city , such a tikal , were larger than previously assumed . the use of lidar revealed numerous house , palace , elevated highway , and defensive fortification . according to archaeologist stephen houston , it is one of the most overwhelming finding in over <number> year of maya archaeology . </s> <section_title_start> colonial era ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> after they arrived in the new world , the spanish started several expedition to guatemala , beginning in <year> . before long , spanish contact resulted in an epidemic that devastated native population . hernn corts , who had led the spanish conquest of mexico , granted a permit to captain gonzalo de alvarado and his brother , pedro de alvarado , to conquer this land . alvarado at first allied himself with the kaqchikel people to fight against their traditional rival the k'iche ' kingdom of q'umarkaj k'iche ' ( quich ) nation . alvarado later turned against the kaqchikel , and eventually brought the entire region under spanish domination . </s> during the colonial period , guatemala wa an audiencia real , a captaincy captaincy-general ( captaincy general of guatemala ) of spain , and a part of new spain ( mexico ) . the first capital , villa de santiago de guatemala ( now known a tecpan guatemala ) , wa founded on <number> july <year> near iximch , the kaqchikel capital city . the capital wa moved to ciudad vieja on <number> november <year> , a a result of a kaqchikel attack on villa de santiago de guatemala . </s> on <number> september <year> , the new capital wa flooded when the lagoon in the volcanic crater of the volcn de agua collapsed due to heavy rain and earthquake ; the capital wa then moved to antigua guatemala in the panchoy valley , now a unesco world heritage site . this city wa destroyed by several earthquake in <year> <number> . the king of spain authorized moving the capital to it current location in the ermita valley , which is named after a catholic church dedicated to the virgin mary . this new capital wa founded on <number> january <year> . </s> <section_title_start> independence and the <number> century ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> on <number> september <year> , the captaincy general of guatemala , an administrative region of the spanish empire consisting of chiapas , guatemala , el salvador , nicaragua , costa rica , and honduras , officially proclaimed it independence from spain . independence from spain wa gained , and the captaincy general of guatemala joined the first mexican empire under agustn de iturbide . </s> under the first empire , mexico reached it greatest territorial extent , stretching from northern california to the province of central america ( excluding panama , which wa then part of colombia ) , which had not initially approved becoming part of the mexican empire but joined the empire shortly after their independence . this region wa formally a part of the new spain throughout the colonial period , but a a practical matter had been administered separately . it wa not until <year> that guatemala created it own flag . </s> in <year> the liberal force of honduran leader francisco morazn and guatemalan jos francisco barrundia invaded guatemala and reached san sur , where they executed cha alvarez , father-in-law of rafael carrera , then a military commander and later the first president of guatemala . the liberal force impaled alvarez 's head on a pike a a warning to follower of the guatemalan caudillo . carrera and his wife petrona who had come to confront morazn a soon a they learned of the invasion and were in mataquescuintla swore they would never forgive morazn even in his grave ; they felt it impossible to respect anyone who would not avenge family member . </s> after sending several envoy , whom carrera would not receive and especially not barrundia whom carrera did not want to murder in cold blood morazn began a scorched-earth offensive , destroying village in his path and stripping them of asset . the carrera force had to hide in the mountain . believing carrera totally defeated , morazn and barrundia marched to guatemala city , and were welcomed a savior by state governor pedro valenzuela and member of the conservative , who proposed to sponsor one of the liberal battalion , while valenzuela and barrundia gave morazn all the guatemalan resource needed to solve any financial problem he had . the criollo people of both party celebrated until dawn that they finally had a criollo caudillo like morazn , who wa able to crush the peasant rebellion . </s> morazn used the proceeds to support los alto and then replaced valenzuela with mariano rivera paz , a member of the aycinena clan , although he did not return to that clan any property confiscated in <year> . in revenge , juan jos de aycinena y piol voted to dissolve the central american federation in san salvador a little later , forcing morazn to return to el salvador to fight for his federal mandate . along the way , morazn increased repression in eastern guatemala , a punishment for helping carrera . knowing that morazn had gone to el salvador , carrera tried to take salam with the small force that remained , but wa defeated , and lost his brother laureano in combat . with just a few men left , he managed to escape , badly wounded , to sanarate . after recovering somewhat , he attacked a detachment in jutiapa and got a small amount of booty which he gave to the volunteer who accompanied him . he then prepared to attack petapa near guatemala city , where he wa victorious , although with heavy casualty . </s> in september of that year , carrera attempted an assault on the capital of guatemala , but the liberal general carlos salazar castro defeated him in the field of villa nueva , guatemala and carrera had to retreat . after unsuccessfully trying to take quetzaltenango , carrera found himself both surrounded and wounded . he had to capitulate to mexican general agustin guzman , who had been in quetzaltenango since vicente filsola 's arrival in <year> . morazn had the opportunity to shoot carrera , but did not , because he needed the support of the guatemalan peasant to counter the attack of francisco ferrera in el salvador . instead , morazn left carrera in charge of a small fort in mita , without any weapon . knowing that morazn wa going to attack el salvador , francisco ferrera gave arm and ammunition to carrera and convinced him to attack guatemala city . </s> meanwhile , despite insistent advice to definitively crush carrera and his force , salazar tried to negotiate with him diplomatically ; he even went a far a to show that he neither feared nor distrusted carrera by removing the fortification of the guatemalan capital , in place since the battle of villa nueva . taking advantage of salazar 's good faith and ferrera 's weapon , carrera took guatemala city by surprise on <number> april <year> ; salazar , mariano glvez and barrundia fled before the arrival of carrera 's militiaman . salazar , in his nightshirt , vaulted roof of neighboring house and sought refuge , reaching the border disguised a a peasant . with salazar gone , carrera reinstated rivera paz a head of state . </s> between <year> and <year> a los alto , central america in the city of quetzaltenango founded the breakaway state of los alto ( country ) and sought independence from guatemala . the most important member of the liberal party of guatemala and liberal enemy of the conservative rgime moved to los alto , leaving their exile in el salvador . the liberal in los alto began severely criticizing the conservative government of rivera paz . los alto wa the region with the main production and economic activity of the former state of guatemala . without los alto , conservative lost many of the resource that had given guatemala hegemony in central america . the government of guatemala tried to reach a peaceful solution , but two year of bloody conflict followed . </s> in <year> , belgium began to act a an external source of support for carrera 's independence movement , in an effort to exert influence in central america . the compagnie belge de colonisation ( belgian colonization company ) , commissioned by belgian leopold i of belgium , became the administrator of santo tomas de castilla replacing the failed british eastern coast of central america commercial and agricultural company . even though the colony eventually crumbled , belgium continued to support carrera in the mid-19th century , although britain continued to be the main business and political partner to carrera . rafael carrera wa elected guatemalan governor in <year> . </s> german guatemalan arrived in the mid-19th century . german settler acquired land and grew coffee plantation in alta verapaz and quetzaltenango . </s> <section_title_start> republic ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> on <number> march <year> , guatemala declared itself an independent republic and carrera became it first president . </s> during the first term a president , carrera brought the country back from extreme conservatism to a traditional moderation ; in <year> , the liberal were able to drive him from office , after the country had been in turmoil for several month . carrera resigned of his own free will and left for mxico . the new liberal regime allied itself with the aycinena family and swiftly passed a law ordering carrera 's execution if he returned to guatemalan soil . </s> the liberal criollo from quetzaltenango were led by general agustn guzmn who occupied the city after corregidor general mariano paredes ( guatemala ) wa called to guatemala city to take over the presidential office . they declared on <number> august <year> that los alto wa an independent state once again . the new state had the support of doroteo vasconcelos ' rgime in el salvador and the rebel guerrilla army of vicente and serapio cruz , who were sworn enemy of carrera . the interim government wa led by guzmn himself and had florencio molina and the priest fernando davila a his cabinet member . on <number> september <year> , the criollo altenses chose a formal government led by fernando antonio martnez . </s> in the meantime , carrera decided to return to guatemala and did so , entering at huehuetenango , where he met with native leader and told them that they must remain united to prevail ; the leader agreed and slowly the segregated native community started developing a new indian identity under carrera 's leadership . in the meantime , in the eastern part of guatemala , the jalapa region became increasingly dangerous ; former president mariano rivera paz and rebel leader vicente cruz were both murdered there after trying to take over the corregidor office in <year> . </s> when carrera arrived to chiantla in huehuetenango , he received two altenses emissary who told him that their soldier were not going to fight his force because that would lead to a native revolt , much like that of <year> ; their only request from carrera wa to keep the native under control . the altenses did not comply , and led by guzmn and his force , they started chasing carrera ; the caudillo hid , helped by his native ally and remained under their protection when the force of miguel garcia granados arrived from guatemala city looking for him . </s> on learning that officer jos vctor zavala had been appointed a corregidor in suchitepquez , carrera and his hundred jakaltek people bodyguard crossed a dangerous jungle infested with jaguar to meet his former friend . zavala not only did not capture him , he agreed to serve under his order , thus sending a strong message to both liberal and conservative in guatemala city that they would have to negotiate with carrera or battle on two front quetzaltenango and jalapa . carrera went back to the quetzaltenango area , while zavala remained in suchitepquez a a tactical maneuver . carrera received a visit from a cabinet member of paredes and told him that he had control of the native population and that he assured paredes that he would keep them appeased . when the emissary returned to guatemala city , he told the president everything carrera said , and added that the native force were formidable . </s> guzmn went to antigua , guatemala to meet with another group of paredes emissary ; they agreed that los alto would rejoin guatemala , and that the latter would help guzmn defeat his enemy and also build a port on the pacific ocean . guzmn wa sure of victory this time , but his plan evaporated when in his absence carrera and his native ally occupied quetzaltenango ; carrera appointed ignacio yrigoyen a corregidor ( position ) and convinced him that he should work with the k'iche ' , q'anjobal and mam people leader to keep the region under control . on his way out , yrigoyen murmured to a friend : `` now he is the king of the indian , indeed ! `` </s> guzmn then left for jalapa , where he struck a deal with the rebel , while luis batres juarros convinced president paredes to deal with carrera . back in guatemala city within a few month , carrera wa commander-in-chief , backed by military and political support of the indian community from the densely populated western highland . during the first presidency , from <year> to <year> , he brought the country back from excessive conservatism to a moderate regime , and with the advice of juan jos de aycinena y piol and pedro de aycinena restored relation with the church in rome with a concordat of <year> ratified in <year> . </s> <section_title_start> second carrera government ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> after carrera returned from exile in <year> the president of el salvador , doroteo vasconcelos , granted asylum to the guatemalan liberal , who harassed the guatemalan government in several different way . jos francisco barrundia established a liberal newspaper for that specific purpose . vasconcelos supported a rebel faction named `` la montaa `` in eastern guatemala , providing and distributing money and weapon . by late <year> , vasconcelos wa getting impatient at the slow progress of the war with guatemala and decided to plan an open attack . under that circumstance , the salvadorean head of state started a campaign against the conservative guatemalan regime , inviting honduras and nicaragua to participate in the alliance ; only the honduras government led by juan lindo accepted . in <year> guatemala defeated an allied army from honduras and el salvador at the battle of la arada . </s> in <year> carrera wa declared `` supreme and perpetual leader of the nation `` for life , with the power to choose his successor . he held that position until he died on <number> april <year> . while he pursued some measure to set up a foundation for economic prosperity to please the conservative landowner , military challenge at home and a three-year war with honduras , el salvador , and nicaragua dominated his presidency . </s> his rivalry with gerardo barrio , president of el salvador , resulted in open war in <year> . at coatepeque , quetzaltenango the guatemalan suffered a battle of coatepeque , which wa followed by a truce . honduras joined with el salvador , and nicaragua and costa rica with guatemala . the contest wa finally settled in favor of carrera , who besieged and occupied san salvador , and dominated honduras and nicaragua . he continued to act in concert with the clerical party , and tried to maintain friendly relation with european government . before he died , carrera nominated his friend and loyal soldier , army marshall vicente cerna y cerna , a his successor . </s> <section_title_start> vicente cerna y cerna regime ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> vicente cerna y cerna wa president of guatemala from <number> may <year> to <number> june <year> . liberal author , described marshall cerna 's government in the following manner : </s> the state and church were a single unit , and the conservative rgime wa strongly allied to the power of regular clergy of the catholic church , who were then among the largest landowner in guatemala . the tight relationship between church and state had been ratified by the concordat of <year> , which wa the law until cerna wa deposed in <year> . even liberal general like realized that rafael carrera 's political and military presence made him practically invincible . thus the general fought under his command , and waitedfor a long timeuntil carrera 's death before beginning their revolt against the tamer cerna . during cerna 's presidency , liberal party member were prosecuted and sent into exile ; among them , those who started the liberal revolution of <year> . </s> in <year> , the merchant guild , consulado de comercio , lost their exclusive court privilege . they had major effect on the economics of the time , and therefore land management . from <year> to <year> , the consulado held a consistent monopolistic position in the regime . </s> <section_title_start> liberal government ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> guatemala 's `` liberal revolution `` came in <year> under the leadership of justo rufino barrio , who worked to modernize the country , improve trade , and introduce new crop and manufacturing . during this era coffee became an important crop for guatemala . barrio had ambition of reuniting central america and took the country to war in an unsuccessful attempt to attain it , losing his life on the battlefield in <year> against force in el salvador . </s> manuel barilla wa president from <number> march <year> to <number> march <year> . manuel barilla wa unique among liberal president of guatemala between <year> and <year> : he handed over power to his successor peacefully . when election time approached , he sent for the three liberal candidate to ask them what their government plan would be . happy with what he heard from general jos mara reyna barrio , barilla made sure that a huge column of quetzaltenango and totonicapn indigenous people came down from the mountain to vote for him . reyna wa elected president . </s> jos mara reina barrio wa president between <year> and <year> . during barrio 's first term in office , the power of the landowner over the rural peasantry increased . he oversaw the rebuilding of part of guatemala city on a grander scale , with wide , parisian-style avenue . he oversaw guatemala hosting the first `` exposicin centroamericana `` ( `` central american fair `` ) in <year> . during his second term , barrio printed bond ( finance ) s to fund his ambitious plan , fueling monetary inflation and the rise of popular opposition to his regime . </s> his administration also worked on improving the road , installing national and international telegraph and introducing electricity to guatemala city . completing a transoceanic railway wa a main objective of his government , with a goal to attract international investor at a time when the panama canal wa not built yet . </s> <section_title_start> manuel estrada cabrera regime ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> after the assassination of general jos mara reina barrio on <number> february <year> , the guatemalan cabinet called an emergency meeting to appoint a new successor , but declined to invite estrada cabrera to the meeting , even though he wa the designated successor to the presidency . there are two different description of how cabrera wa able to become president . the first state that cabrera entered the cabinet meeting `` with pistol drawn `` to assert his entitlement to the presidency , while the second state that he showed up unarmed to the meeting and demanded the presidency by virtue of being the designated successor . </s> the first civilian guatemalan head of state in over <number> year , estrada cabrera overcame resistance to his regime by august <year> and called for election in september , which he won handily . in <year> the legislature convened for the election of president estrada cabrera , who triumphed thanks to the large number of soldier and policeman who went to vote in civilian clothes and to the large number of illiterate family that they brought with them to the poll . </s> one of estrada cabrera 's most famous and most bitter legacy wa allowing the entry of the united fruit company ( ufco ) into the guatemalan economic and political arena . a a member of the liberalism in latin america , he sought to encourage development of the nation 's infrastructure of [ railroad ] s , and [ [ sea port for the sake of expanding the export economy . by the time estrada cabrera assumed the presidency there had been repeated effort to construct a railroad from the major port of puerto barrio to the capital , guatemala city . due to lack of funding exacerbated by the collapse of the internal coffee trade , the railway fell short of it goal . estrada cabrera decided , without consulting the legislature or judiciary , that striking a deal with the ufco wa the only way to finish the railway . cabrera signed a contract with ufco 's minor cooper keith in <year> that gave the company tax exemption , land grant , and control of all railroad on the atlantic side . </s> estrada cabrera often employed brutal method to assert his authority . right at the beginning of his first presidential period he started prosecuting his political rival and soon established a well-organized web of spy . one american ambassador returned to the united state after he learned the dictator had given order to poison him . former president manuel barilla wa stabbed to death in mexico city . estrada cabrera responded violently to worker ' strike against ufco . in one incident , when ufco went directly to estrada cabrera to resolve a strike ( after the armed force refused to respond ) , the president ordered an armed unit to enter a worker ' compound . the force `` arrived in the night , firing indiscriminately into the worker ' sleeping quarter , wounding and killing an unspecified number . `` </s> in <year> estrada faced serious revolt against his rule ; the rebel were supported by the government of some of the other central american nation , but estrada succeeded in putting them down . election were held by the people against the will of estrada cabrera and thus he had the president-elect murdered in retaliation . in <year> estrada narrowly survived an assassination attempt when a bomb exploded near his carriage . it ha been suggested that the extreme despotic characteristic of estrada did not emerge until after an attempt on his life in <year> . </s> guatemala city wa badly damaged in the <year> guatemala earthquake . </s> estrada cabrera continued in power until forced to resign after new revolt in <year> . by that time his power had declined drastically and he wa reliant upon the loyalty of a few general . while the united state threatened intervention if he wa removed through revolution , a bipartisan coalition came together to remove him from the presidency . he wa removed from office after the national assembly charged that he wa mentally incompetent , and appointed carlos herrera in his place on <number> april <year> . </s> <section_title_start> jorge ubico regime ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> the great depression began in <year> and badly damaged the guatemalan economy , causing a rise in unemployment , and leading to unrest among worker and laborer . afraid of a popular revolt , the guatemalan landed elite lent their support to jorge ubico , who had become well known for `` efficiency and cruelty `` a a provincial governor . ubico won the election that followed in <year> , in which he wa the only candidate . after his election his policy quickly became authoritarian . he replaced the system of debt peonage with a brutally enforced vagrancy ( people ) law , requiring all men of working age who did not own land to work a minimum of <number> day of hard labor . his government used unpaid indian labor to build road and railway . ubico also froze wage at very low level , and passed a law allowing land-owners complete immunity from prosecution for any action they took to defend their property , an action described by historian a legalizing murder . he greatly strengthened the police force , turning it into one of the most efficient and ruthless in latin america . he gave them greater authority to shoot and imprison people suspected of breaking the labor law . these law created tremendous resentment against him among agricultural laborer . the government became highly militarized ; under his rule , every provincial governor wa a general in the army . </s> ubico continued his predecessor 's policy of making massive concession to the united fruit company , often at a cost to guatemala . he granted the company of public land in exchange for a promise to build a port , a promise he later waived . since it entry into guatemala , the united fruit company had expanded it land-holdings by displacing farmer and converting their farmland to banana plantation . this process accelerated under ubico 's presidency , with the government doing nothing to stop it . the company received import duty and real estate tax exemption from the government and controlled more land than any other individual or group . it also controlled the sole railroad in the country , the sole facility capable of producing electricity , and the port facility at puerto barrio on the atlantic coast . </s> ubico saw the united state a an ally against the supposed communist threat of mexico , and made effort to gain it support . when the u [ united state declaration of war upon germany ( <year> ) declared war ] ] against germany in <year> , ubico acted on american instruction and arrested all people in guatemala of german guatemalan . he also permitted the u to establish an air base in guatemala , with the stated aim of protecting the panama canal . however , ubico wa an admirer of european fascism , such a francisco franco and benito mussolini , and considered himself to be `` another napoleon bonaparte `` . he occasionally compared himself to adolf hitler . he dressed ostentatiously and surrounded himself with statue and painting of napoleon , regularly commenting on the similarity between their appearance . he militarized numerous political and social institutionsincluding the post office , school , and symphony orchestrasand placed military officer in charge of many government post . </s> <section_title_start> guatemalan revolution ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> on <number> july <year> ubico wa forced to resign from the presidency in response to a wave of protest and a general strike inspired by brutal labor condition among plantation worker . his chosen replacement , general juan federico ponce vaides , wa forced out of office on <number> october <year> by a coup d'tat led by major francisco javier arana and captain jacobo rbenz guzmn . about <number> people were killed in the coup . the country wa then led by a military junta made up of arana , rbenz , and jorge toriello garrido . </s> the junta organized guatemala 's first free election , which the philosophically conservative writer and teacher juan jos arvalo , who wanted to turn the country into a liberalism capitalism society won with a majority of <number> . his `` christian socialism `` policy were inspired to a large extent by the u.s. new deal of president franklin d. roosevelt during the great depression . arvalo built new health center , increased funding for education , and drafted a more liberal labor law , while criminalizing union in workplace with le than <number> worker , and cracking down on communist . although arvalo wa popular among nationalist , he had enemy in the church and the military , and faced at least <number> coup attempt during his presidency . </s> arvalo wa constitutionally prohibited from contesting the <year> election . the largely free and fair election were won by jacobo rbenz guzmn , arvalo 's defense minister . rbenz continued the moderate capitalist approach of arvalo . his most important policy wa decree <number> , a sweeping agrarian reform bill passed in <year> . decree <number> transferred uncultivated land to landless peasant . only <number> of the nearly <number> private land-holdings were affected by the law , which benefited approximately <number> individual , or one-sixth of the population . </s> <section_title_start> coup and civil war ( <year> <number> ) <section_title_end> </s> despite their popularity within the country , the reform of the guatemalan revolution were disliked by the united state government , which wa predisposed by the cold war to see it a communist , and the united fruit company ( ufco ) , whose hugely profitable business had been affected by the end to brutal labor practice . the attitude of the u.s. government wa also influenced by a propaganda campaign carried out by the ufco . </s> u.s. president harry truman authorized operation pbfortune to topple rbenz in <year> , with the support of nicaraguan dictator anastasio somoza garca , but the operation wa aborted when too many detail became public . dwight d. eisenhower wa elected u.s. president in <year> , promising to take a harder line against communism ; the close link that his staff member john foster dulles and allen dulles had to the ufco also predisposed him to act against rbenz . eisenhower authorized the cia to carry out operation pbsuccess in august <year> . the cia armed , funded , and trained a force of <number> men led by carlos castillo armas . the force invaded guatemala on <number> june <year> , backed by a heavy campaign of psychological warfare , including bombing of guatemala city and an anti-rbenz radio station claiming to be genuine news . the invasion force fared poorly militarily , but the psychological warfare and the possibility of a u.s. invasion intimidated the guatemalan army , which refused to fight . rbenz resigned on <number> june . </s> following negotiation in san salvador , carlos castillo armas became president on <number> july <year> . election were held in early october , from which all political party were barred from participating . castillo armas wa the only candidate and won the election with <number> of the vote . castillo armas reversed decree <number> and ruled until <number> july <year> , when he wa assassinated by romeo vsquez , a member of his personal guard . after the rigged election that followed , general jos miguel ramn ydgoras fuentes assumed power . he is celebrated for challenging the mexican president to a gentleman 's duel on the bridge on the south border to end a feud on the subject of illegal fishing by mexican boat on guatemala 's pacific coast , two of which were sunk by the guatemalan air force . ydigoras authorized the training of <number> anti-fidel castro cuban in guatemala . he also provided airstrip in the region of petn ( department ) for what later became the us-sponsored , failed bay of pig invasion in <year> . ydigoras ' government wa ousted in <year> when the guatemalan air force attacked several military base ; the coup wa led by his defense minister , colonel enrique peralta azurdia . </s> in <year> , the junta called an election , which permitted arevalo to return from exile and run . however , a coup from within the military , backed by the kennedy administration , prevented the election from taking place , and forestalled a likely victory for arevalo . the new rgime intensified the campaign of terror against the guerrilla that had begun under ydgoras-fuentes . </s> in <year> , julio csar mndez montenegro wa elected president of guatemala under the banner `` democratic opening `` . mendez montenegro wa the candidate of the revolutionary party , a center-left party that had it origin in the post-ubico era . during this time rightist paramilitary organization , such a the `` white hand `` ( mano blanca ) , and the anticommunist secret army ( ejrcito secreto anticomunista ) were formed . those group were the forerunner of the infamous `` death squad `` . military adviser from the special force ( united state army ) ( green beret ) were sent to guatemala to train these troop and help transform the army into a modern counter-insurgency force , which eventually made it the most sophisticated in central america . </s> in <year> , colonel carlos manuel arana osorio wa elected president . by <year> , member of the guerrilla movement entered the country from mexico and settled in the western highland . in the guatemalan general election , <year> , general kjell eugenio laugerud garca defeated general efran ro montt , a candidate of the christian democratic party , who claimed that he had been cheated out of a victory through fraud . </s> on <number> february <year> , a major earthquake destroyed several city and caused more than <number> death , especially among the poor , whose housing wa substandard . the government 's failure to respond rapidly to the aftermath of the earthquake and to relieve homelessness gave rise to widespread discontent , which contributed to growing popular unrest . general romeo lucas garca assumed power in <year> in a fraudulent election . </s> the <year> saw the rise of two new guerrilla organization , the guerrilla army of the poor ( egp ) and the organization of the people in arm ( orpa ) . they began guerrilla attack that included urban and rural warfare , mainly against the military and some civilian supporter of the army . the army and the paramilitary force responded with a brutal counter-insurgency campaign that resulted in ten of thousand of civilian death . in <year> , the u.s. president , jimmy carter , who had until then been providing public support for the government force , ordered a ban on all military aid to the guatemalan army because of it widespread and systematic abuse of human right . however , document have since come to light that suggest that american aid continued throughout the carter year , through clandestine channel . </s> on <number> january <year> , a group of indigenous k'iche ' people k'iche ' took over the spanish embassy to protest army massacre in the countryside . the guatemalan government armed force launched an assault that killed almost everyone inside in a burning of the spanish embassy . the guatemalan government claimed that the activist set the fire , thus self-immolation themselves . however the spanish ambassador survived the fire and disputed this claim , saying that the guatemalan police intentionally killed almost everyone inside and set the fire to erase trace of their act . a a result , the government of spain broke off diplomatic relation with guatemala . </s> this government wa overthrown in <year> and general efran ro montt wa named president of the military junta . he continued the bloody campaign of torture , forced disappearance , and `` scorched earth `` warfare . the country became a pariah state internationally , although the regime received considerable support from the reagan administration , and reagan himself described ro montt a `` a man of great personal integrity . `` ro montt wa overthrown by general scar humberto meja victores , who called for an election of a national constituent assembly to write a new constitution , leading to a free election in <year> , won by marco vinicio cerezo arvalo , the candidate of the christian democracy party . </s> in <year> , the four guerrilla group , egp , orpa , far and pgt , merged and formed the guatemalan national revolutionary unity , influenced by the el salvador guerrilla farabundo mart national liberation front , the nicaraguan sandinista national liberation front and cuba 's government , in order to become stronger . a a result of the army 's `` scorched earth `` tactic in the countryside , more than <number> guatemalan fled across the border to mexico . the mexican government placed the refugee in camp in chiapas and tabasco . </s> in <year> , the nobel peace prize wa awarded to rigoberta mench for her effort to bring international attention to the government-sponsored guatemalan genocide . </s> <section_title_start> <year> <number> <section_title_end> </s> the guatemalan civil war ended in <year> with a peace accord between the guerrilla and the government , negotiated by the united nation through intense brokerage by nation such a norway and spain . both side made major concession . the guerrilla fighter disarmed and received land to work . according to the u.n.-sponsored truth commission ( the commission for historical clarification ) , government force and state-sponsored , cia-trained paramilitary were responsible for over <number> of the human right violation during the war . </s> in the last few year , million of document related to crime committed during the civil war have been found abandoned by the former guatemalan police . the family of over <number> guatemalan activist who forced disappearance during the civil war are now reviewing the document , which have been digitized . this could lead to further legal action . </s> during the first ten year of the civil war , the victim of the state-sponsored terror were primarily student , worker , professional , and opposition figure , but in the last year they were thousand of mostly rural maya people farmer and non-combatants . more than <number> maya village were destroyed and over <number> million people became refugee or displaced within guatemala . </s> in <year> , the catholic archdiocese of guatemala began the recovery of historical memory ( remhi ) project , known in spanish a `` el proyecto de la recuperacin de la memoria histrica `` , to collect the fact and history of guatemala 's long civil war and confront the truth of those year . on <number> april <year> , remhi presented the result of it work in the report `` guatemala : nunca m ! `` . this report summarized testimony and statement of thousand of witness and victim of repression during the civil war . `` the report laid the blame for <number> per cent of the atrocity at the door of the guatemalan army and it collaborator within the social and political elite . `` </s> catholic bishop juan jos gerardi conedera worked on the recovery of historical memory project and two day after he announced the release of it report on victim of the guatemalan civil war , `` guatemala : nunca m ! `` , in april <year> , bishop gerardi wa attacked in his garage and beaten to death . in <year> , in the first trial in a civilian court of member of the military in guatemalan history , three army officer were convicted of his death and sentenced to <number> year in prison . a priest wa convicted a an accomplice and wa sentenced to <number> year in prison . </s> according to the report , recuperacin de la memoria histrica ( remhi ) , some <number> people died . more than one million people were forced to flee their home and hundred of village were destroyed . the historical clarification commission attributed more than <number> of all documented violation of human right to guatemala 's military government , and estimated that maya indian accounted for <number> of the victim . it concluded in <year> that state action constituted genocide . </s> in some area such a baja verapaz , the truth commission found that the guatemalan state engaged in an intentional policy of genocide against particular ethnic group in the guatemalan civil war . in <year> , u.s. president bill clinton said that the united state had been wrong to have provided support to the guatemalan military force that took part in these brutal civilian killing . </s> <section_title_start> since <year> <section_title_end> </s> since the peace accord guatemala ha had both economic growth and successive democratic election , most recently in <year> . in the <year> election , alejandro giammattei won the presidency . he assumed office in january <year> . </s> in january <year> efrain rio montt , the former dictator of guatemala , appeared in a guatemalan court on genocide charge . during the hearing , the government presented evidence of over <number> incident involving at least <number> death , <number> rape , and the displacement of nearly <number> guatemalan during his <number>-month rule from <year> to <year> . the prosecution wanted him incarcerated because he wa viewed a a flight risk but he remained free on bail , under house arrest and guarded by the guatemalan national civil police ( pnc ) . on <number> may <year> , rio montt wa found guilty and sentenced to <number> year in prison . it marked the first time that a national court had found a former head of state guilty of genocide . the conviction wa later overturned , and montt 's trial resumed in january <year> . in august <year> , a guatemalan court ruled that rio montt could stand trial for genocide and crime against humanity , but that he could not be sentenced due to his age and deteriorating health . </s> ex-president alfonso portillo wa arrested in january <year> while trying to flee guatemala . he wa acquitted in may <year> , by a panel of judge that threw out some of the evidence and discounted certain witness a unreliable . the guatemalan attorney-general , claudia paz y paz , called the verdict `` a terrible message of injustice , `` and `` a wake up call about the power structure . `` in it appeal , the international commission against impunity in guatemala ( cicig ) , a un judicial group assisting the guatemalan government , called the decision 's assessment of the meticulously-documented evidence against portillo cabrera `` whimsical `` and said the decision 's assertion that the president of guatemala and his minister had no responsibility for handling public fund ran counter to the constitution and law of guatemala . a new york grand jury had indicted portillo cabrera in <year> for embezzlement ; following his acquittal on those charge in guatemala that country 's supreme court authorized his extradition to the u . the guatemalan judiciary is deeply corrupt and the selection committee for new nomination ha been captured by criminal element . </s> <section_title_start> prez molina government and `` la lnea `` <section_title_end> </s> retired general otto prez molina wa elected president in <year> along with roxana baldetti , the first woman ever elected vice-president in guatemala ; they began their term in office on <number> january <year> . but on <number> april <year> , a united nation ( un ) anti-corruption agency report implicated several high-profile politician including baldetti 's private secretary , juan carlos monzn , and the director of the guatemalan internal revenue service ( sat ) . the revelation provoked more public outrage than had been seen since the presidency of general kjell eugenio laugerud garca . the international commission against impunity in guatemala ( cicig ) worked with the guatemalan attorney-general to reveal the scam known a `` la lnea corruption case `` , following a year-long investigation that included telephone tapping . </s> official received bribe from importer in exchange for discounted import tariff , a practice rooted in a long tradition of custom corruption in the country , a a fund-raising tactic of successive military government for counterinsurgency operation during guatemala 's <number>-year-long guatemala civil war . </s> a facebook event using the hashtag # renunciaya ( resign now ) invited citizen to go downtown in guatemala city to ask for baldetti 's resignation . within day , over <number> people rsvped that they would attend . organiser made clear that no political party or group wa behind the event , and instructed protester at the event to follow the law . they also urged people to bring water , food and sunblock , but not to cover their face or wear political party color . ten of thousand of people took to the street of guatemala city . they protested in front of the presidential palace . baldetti resigned a few day later . she wa forced to remain in guatemala when the united state revoked her visa . the guatemalan government arraigned her , since it had enough evidence to suspect her involvement in the `` la linea `` scandal . the prominence of u ambassador todd robinson in the guatemalan political scene once the scandal broke led to the suspicion that the u government wa behind the investigation , perhaps because it needed an honest government in guatemala to counter the presence of china and russia in the region . </s> the un anti-corruption committee ha reported on other case since then , and more than <number> government official have stepped down . some were arrested . two of those case involved two former presidential private secretary : juan de dios rodrguez in the guatemalan social service and gustave martnez , who wa involved in a bribery scandal at the coal power plant company . martnez wa also perez molina 's son-in-law . </s> leader of the political opposition have also been implicated in cicig investigation : several legislator and member of libertad democrtica renovada party ( lider ) were formally accused of bribery-related issue , prompting a large decline in the electoral prospect of it presidential candidate , manuel baldizn , who until april had been almost certain to become the next guatemalan president in the <number> september <year> presidential election . baldizn 's popularity steeply declined and he filed accusation with the organization of american state against cicig leader ivn velsquez of international obstruction in guatemalan internal affair . </s> cicig reported it case so often on thursday that guatemalan coined the term `` cicig thursday `` . but a friday press conference brought the crisis to it peak : on friday <number> august <year> , the cicig and attorney general thelma aldana presented enough evidence to convince the public that both president prez molina and former vice president baldetti were the actual leader of `` la lnea `` . baldetti wa arrested the same day and an impeachment wa requested for the president . several cabinet member resigned and the clamor for the president 's resignation grew after perez molina defiantly assured the nation in a televised message broadcast on <number> august <year> that he wa not going to resign . </s> thousand of protester took to the street again , this time to demand the increasingly isolated president 's resignation . guatemala 's congress named a commission of five legislator to consider whether to remove the president 's immunity from prosecution . the supreme court approved . a major day of action kicked off early on <number> august , with march and roadblock across the country . urban group who had spearheaded regular protest since the scandal broke in april , on the <number> sought to unite with the rural and indigenous organization who orchestrated the road block . </s> the strike in guatemala city wa full of a diverse and peaceful crowd ranging from the indigenous poor to the well-heeled , and it included many student from public and private university . hundred of school and business closed in support of the protest . the comit coordinador de asociaciones agrcolas , comerciales , industriales y financieras ( cacif ) guatemala 's most powerful business leader , issued a statement demanding that prez molina step down , and urged congress to withdraw his immunity from prosecution . </s> the attorney general 's office released it own statement , calling for the president 's resignation `` to prevent ungovernability that could destabilize the nation . `` a pressure mounted , the president 's former minister of defence and of the interior , who had been named in the corruption investigation and resigned , abruptly left the country . prez molina meanwhile had been losing support by the day . the private sector called for his resignation ; however , he also managed to get support from entrepreneur that were not affiliated with the private sector chamber : mario lpez estrada grandchild of former dictator manuel estrada cabrera and the billionaire owner of cellular phone company had some of his executive assume the vacated cabinet position . </s> the guatemalan radio station emisoras unidas reported exchanging text message with perez molina . asked whether he planned to resign , he wrote : `` i will face whatever is necessary to face , and what the law requires . `` some protester demanded the general election be postponed , both because of the crisis and because it wa plagued with accusation of irregularity . others warned that suspending the vote could lead to an institutional vacuum . however , on <number> september <year> prez molina resigned , a day after congress impeached him . on <number> september <year> he wa summoned to the justice department for his first legal audience for the la linea corruption case . </s> in june <year> a united nations-backed prosecutor described the administration of prez molina a a crime syndicate and outlined another corruption case , this one dubbed cooperacha ( kick-in ) . the head of the social security institute and at least five other minister pooled fund to buy him luxurious gift such a motorboat , spending over $ <number> million in three year . </s> <section_title_start> geography <section_title_end> </s> guatemala is mountainous with small patch of desert and sand dune , all hilly valley , except for the south coast and the vast northern lowland of petn ( department ) department . two mountain chain enter guatemala from west to east , dividing guatemala into three major region : the highland , where the mountain are located ; the pacific coast , south of the mountain and the petn region , north of the mountain . </s> all major city are located in the highland and pacific coast region ; by comparison , petn is sparsely populated . these three region vary in climate , elevation , and landscape , providing dramatic contrast between hot , humid tropical lowland and colder , drier highland peak . volcn tajumulco , at , is the highest point in the central american country . </s> the river are short and shallow in the pacific drainage basin , larger and deeper in the caribbean and the gulf of mexico drainage basin . these river include the polochic river and dulce river ( guatemala ) , which drain into lake izabal , the motagua river , the sarstoon river , which form the boundary with belize , and the usumacinta river , which form the boundary between petn and chiapas , mexico . </s> <section_title_start> natural disasters <section_title_end> </s> guatemala 's location between the caribbean sea and pacific ocean make it a target for hurricane such a hurricane mitch in <year> and hurricane stan in october <year> , which killed more than <number> people . the damage wa not wind-related , but rather due to significant flooding and resulting mudflow . the most recent wa hurricane eta in november <year> , which wa responsible for more than <number> missing or killed with the final tally still uncertain . </s> guatemala 's highland lie along the motagua fault , part of the boundary between the caribbean plate and north american plate tectonic plate . this fault ha been responsible for several major earthquake in historic time , including a <number> magnitude tremor on <number> february <year> which killed more than <number> people . in addition , the middle america trench , a major subduction zone lie off the pacific coast . here , the coco plate is sinking beneath the caribbean plate , producing volcanic activity inland of the coast . guatemala ha <number> volcano , four of them active : pacaya , santiaguito , volcn de fuego , and volcn tacan . </s> natural disaster have a long history in this geologically active part of the world . for example , two of the three antigua guatemala # history of the capital of guatemala have been due to volcanic mudflows in <year> and earthquake in <year> . </s> <section_title_start> biodiversity <section_title_end> </s> guatemala ha <number> ecoregions ranging from mangrove forest to both ocean littoral with <number> different ecosystem . guatemala ha <number> listed wetland , including five lake , <number> lagoon , <number> river , and four swamp . tikal national park wa the first mixed unesco world heritage site . guatemala is a country of distinct fauna . it ha some <year> known specie . of these , <number> are endemism and <number> are threatened . guatemala is home to at least <number> specie of vascular plant , of which <number> are endemic . <number> of guatemala is protected under iucn category i-v. </s> the maya biosphere reserve in the department of petn ( department ) ha <number> ha , making it the second-largest forest in central america after bosawas . it had a <year> forest landscape integrity index mean score of <number>/10 , ranking it <number> globally out of <number> country . </s> <section_title_start> government <section_title_end> </s> <section_title_start> political system <section_title_end> </s> guatemala is a constitutional democratic republic whereby the president of guatemala is both [ of state ] and [ of government ] , and of a multi-party system . executive power is exercised by the government . legislative power is vested in both the government and the congress of the republic of guatemala . the judiciary is independent of the executive and the legislature . </s> on <number> september <year> , otto prez molina resigned a president of guatemala due to la linea corruption case and wa replaced by alejandro maldonado until january <year> . congress appointed former universidad de san carlos de guatemala president alfonso fuentes soria a the new vice president to replace maldonado . </s> jimmy morale assumed office on <number> january <year> . </s> <section_title_start> foreign relation <section_title_end> </s> guatemala ha long claimed all or part of the territory of neighboring belize . due to this territorial dispute , guatemala did not recognize belize 's independence until <number> september <year> , but the dispute is not resolved . negotiation are currently under way under the auspex of the organization of american state to conclude it . </s> <section_title_start> military <section_title_end> </s> guatemala ha a modest military , with between <number> and <number> personnel . </s> in <year> , guatemala signed the united nation treaty on the prohibition of nuclear weapon . </s> <section_title_start> administrative division <section_title_end> </s> guatemala is divided into <number> department ( subnational entity ) ( spanish language : departamentos ) and sub-divided into about <number> municipality ( spanish language : municipios ) . </s> <section_title_start> human right <section_title_end> </s> killing and death squad have been common in guatemala since the end of the civil war in <year> . they often had tie to clandestine security apparatus ( cuerpos ilegales y aparatos clandestinos de seguridad ciacs ) , organization of current and former member of the military involved in organized crime . they had significant influence , now somewhat lessened , but extrajudicial killing continue . in july <year> , the inter-american court condemned the <number> july <year> massacre of <number> achi-maya in plan de sanchez , and for the first time in it history , ruled the guatemalan army had committed genocide . it wa the first ruling by the court against the guatemalan state for any of the <number> massacre reported in it <year> scorched-earth campaign . in those massacre , <number> percent of the victim were maya and <number> percent ladino . </s> { class= `` wikitable `` style= `` align : center ; `` </s> ! colspan=2 extra-judicial killing in guatemala </s> - </s> style= `` text-align :
