established in <year> </s> category : state and territory established in <year> </s> category : transcontinental country <article_end> <article_start> </s> ireland ( ; ire ; ulster scot dialect ulster-scots : airlann ) is an island in the north atlantic ocean . it is separated from great britain to it east by the north channel ( great britain and ireland ) , the irish sea , and st george 's channel . ireland is the list of island of the british isle second-largest island of the british isle , the list of european island by area third-largest in europe , and the list of island by area twentieth-largest on earth . </s> geopolitically , ireland is divided between the republic of ireland ( officially name of the irish state ) , which cover five-sixths of the island , and northern ireland , which is part of the united kingdom . in <year> , the irish population analysis wa about <number> ; million , ranking it the list of european island by population second-most populous island in europe after great britain . a of <year> , <number> ; million live in the republic of ireland , and <number> ; million live in northern ireland . </s> the geography of ireland comprises relatively low-lying mountain surrounding a central plain , with river of ireland extending inland . it lush vegetation is a product of it mild but changeable climate which is free of extreme in temperature . much of ireland wa woodland until the end of the middle age . today , woodland make up about <number> of the island , compared with a european average of over <number> , and most of it is non-native conifer plantation . there are twenty-six extant land mammal specie native to ireland . the climate of ireland is influenced by the atlantic ocean and thus very moderate , and winter are milder than expected for such a northerly area , although summer are cooler than those in continental europe . rainfall and cloud cover are abundant . </s> the earliest evidence of human presence in ireland is dated at <number> bc . gaelic ireland had emerged by the <number> century ad . the island wa christianised from the <number> century onward . following the <number> century norman invasion of ireland anglo-norman invasion , kingdom of england claimed sovereignty . however , english rule did not extend over the whole island until the <number>17th century tudor conquest of ireland , which led to plantation of ireland . in the <year> , a system of protestant ascendancy wa designed to materially disadvantage the catholic church majority and protestant dissenter , and wa extended during the <number> century . with the act of union <year> in <year> , ireland became country of the united kingdom the united kingdom of great britain and ireland . a irish war of independence in the early <number> century wa followed by the partition of ireland , creating the irish free state , which became increasingly sovereign over the following decade , and northern ireland , which remained a part of the united kingdom . northern ireland saw much the trouble . this subsided following good friday agreement in <year> . in <year> the republic of ireland joined the european economic community while the united kingdom , and northern ireland , a part of it , did the same . </s> irish culture ha had a significant influence on other culture , especially in the field of irish literature . alongside mainstream western culture , a strong indigenous culture exists , a expressed through gaelic game , irish music and the irish language . the island 's culture share many feature with that of great britain , including the english language , and sport such a association football , rugby football , [ racing ] , and golf . </s> <section_title_start> etymology <section_title_end> </s> the name ireland and ire derive from old irish riu , a goddess in irish mythology first recorded in the ninth century . the etymology of riu is disputed but may derive from the proto-indo-european root * , referring to flowing water . </s> <section_title_start> history <section_title_end> </s> <section_title_start> prehistoric ireland <section_title_end> </s> during the last glacial period , and until about <number> bc , most of ireland wa periodically covered in ice . sea level were lower and ireland , like great britain , formed part of continental europe . by <number> bc , rising sea level caused by ice melting caused ireland to become separated from great britain . later , around <year> bc , great britain became separated from continental europe . the earliest evidence of human presence in ireland is dated at <number> bc , demonstrated by a butchered bear bone found in a cave in county clare . by about <year> bc , more sustained occupation of the island ha been shown , with evidence for mesolithic community around the island . </s> some time before <year> ; bc , neolithic settler introduced cereal cultivar , domesticated animal such a cattle and sheep , large timber building , and stone monument . the earliest evidence for farming in ireland or great britain is from ferriter 's cove , county kerry , where a flint knife , cattle bone and a sheep 's tooth were radiocarbon dating carbon-dated to c. ; <year> ; bc . field system were developed in different part of ireland , including at the cide field , that ha been preserved beneath a blanket of peat in present-day tyrawley . an extensive field system , arguably the oldest in the world , consisted of small division separated by dry-stone wall . the field were farmed for several century between <year> bc and <year> bc . wheat and barley were the principal crop . </s> the bronze age ; began around <year> bc , with technology changing people 's everyday life during this period through innovation such a the wheel ; harnessing ox ; weaving ; brewing alcohol ( drug ) ; and skilful metalworking , which produced new weapon and tool , along with fine gold decoration and jewellery , such a brooch and torcs . </s> <section_title_start> emergence of celtic ireland <section_title_end> </s> how and when the island became celtic ha been debated for close to a century , with the migration of the celt being one of the more enduring theme of archaeological and linguistic study . the most recent genetic research strongly associate the spread of indo-european language ( including celtic ) through western europe with a people bringing a composite beaker culture , with it arrival in britain and ireland dated to around the middle of the third millennium ; bc . according to john t. koch and others , ireland in the late bronze age wa part of a maritime trading-network culture called the atlantic bronze age that also included britain , western france and iberia , and that this is where celtic language developed . this contrast with the traditional view that their origin lie in mainland europe with the hallstatt culture . </s> the long-standing traditional view is that the celtic language , ogham script and culture were brought to ireland by wave of invading or migrating celt from mainland europe . this theory draw on the lebor gabla renn , a medieval christian pseudo-history of ireland , along with the presence of celtic culture , language and artifact found in ireland such a celtic bronze spear , shield , torcs and other finely crafted celtic associated possession . the theory hold that there were four separate celtic invasion of ireland . the priteni were said to be the first , followed by the belgae from northern gaul and britain . later , laighin tribe from armorica ( present-day brittany ) were said to have invaded ireland and britain more or le simultaneously . lastly , the milesians ( irish ) ( gael ) were said to have reached ireland from either northern iberia or southern gaul . it wa claimed that a second wave named the euerni , belonging to the belgae people of northern gaul , began arriving about the sixth century bc . they were said to have given their name to the island . </s> the theory wa advanced in part because of lack of archaeological evidence for large-scale celtic immigration , though it is accepted that such movement are notoriously difficult to identify . historical linguist are skeptical that this method alone could account for the absorption of celtic language , with some saying that an assumed processional view of celtic linguistic formation is 'an especially hazardous exercise ' . genetic lineage investigation into the area of celtic migration to ireland ha led to finding that showed no significant difference in mitochondrial dna between ireland and large area of continental europe , in contrast to part of the y-chromosome pattern . when taking both into account , a study concluded that modern celtic speaker in ireland could be thought of a european `` atlantic celt `` showing a shared ancestry throughout the atlantic zone from northern iberia to western scandinavia rather than substantially central european . </s> in <year> , research showed that occurrence of genetic marker for the earliest farmer wa almost eliminated by beaker-culture immigrant : they carried what wa then a new y-chromosome r1b marker , believed to have originated in iberia about <year> bc . the prevalence amongst modern irish men of this mutation is a remarkable <number> , the highest in the world , and closely matched in other population along the atlantic fringe down to spain . a similar genetic replacement happened with lineage in mitochondrial dna . this conclusion is supported by recent research carried out by the geneticist david reich ( geneticist ) , who say : british and irish skeleton from the bronze age that followed the beaker period had at most <number> percent ancestry from the first farmer of these island , with other <number> percent from people like those associated with the bell beaker culture in the netherlands . he suggests that it wa beaker user who introduced an indo-european language , represented here by celtic ( i.e . a new language and culture introduced directly by migration and genetic replacement ) . </s> <section_title_start> late antiquity and early medieval times <section_title_end> </s> the earliest written record of ireland come from classical greco-roman world greco-roman geographer . ptolemy in his almagest refers to ireland a mikra brettania ( `` little britain `` ) , in contrast to the larger island , which he called megale brettania ( `` great britain `` ) . in his later work , geography ( ptolemy ) , ptolemy refers to ireland a hibernia and to great britain a albion . these 'new ' name were likely to have been the local name for the island at the time . the earlier name , exonym and endonym , were likely to have been coined before direct contact with local people wa made . </s> the ancient roman referred to ireland by this name too in it latinisation of name form , hibernia , or scotia . ptolemy record sixteen nation inhabiting every part of ireland in <number> ad . the relationship between the roman empire and the kingdom of ancient ireland is unclear . however , a number of find of roman coin have been made , for example at the iron age settlement of freestone hill near gowran and newgrange . </s> ireland continued a a patchwork of rival kingdom ; however , beginning in the <number> century , a concept of national kingship gradually became articulated through the concept of a high king of ireland . medieval irish literature portrays an almost unbroken sequence of high king stretching back thousand of year , but modern historian believe the scheme wa constructed in the <number> century to justify the status of powerful political grouping by projecting the origin of their rule into the remote past . </s> all of the irish kingdom had their own king but were nominally subject to the high king . the high king wa drawn from the rank of the provincial king and ruled also the royal kingdom of meath , with a ceremonial capital at the hill of tara . the concept did not become a political reality until the viking age # ireland and even then wa not a consistent one . ireland did have a culturally unifying rule of law : the early written judicial system , the brehon law , administered by a professional class of jurist known a the brehons . </s> the chronicle of ireland record that in <number> , bishop palladius ( bishop of ireland ) arrived in ireland on a mission from pope celestine i to minister to the irish `` already believing in christ `` . the same chronicle record that saint patrick , ireland 's best known patron saint of place , arrived the following year . there is continued debate over the mission of palladius and patrick , but the consensus is that they both took place and that the older druid tradition collapsed in the face of the new religion . irish christian scholar excelled in the study of latin and greek learning and christian theology . in the monastic culture that followed the christianisation of ireland , latin and greek learning wa preserved in ireland during the middle age in contrast to elsewhere in western europe , where the early middle age followed the fall of the western roman empire . </s> the art of illuminated manuscript , metalworking and sculpture flourished and produced treasure such a the book of kells , ornate jewellery and the many carved stone cross that still dot the island today . a mission founded in <number> on iona by the irish monk saint columba began hiberno-scottish mission work that spread celtic christianity and learning to scotland , anglo-saxon england and the frankish empire on continental europe after the fall of rome . these mission continued until the late middle age , establishing monastery and centre of learning , producing scholar such a sedulius scottus and johannes eriugena and exerting much influence in europe . </s> from the <number> century , wave of viking raider plundered irish monastery and town . these raid added to a pattern of raiding and endemic warfare that wa already deep-seated in ireland . the viking were involved in establishing most of the major coastal settlement in ireland : dublin , limerick , county cork , wexford , waterford , a well a other smaller settlement . </s> <section_title_start> norman and english invasions <section_title_end> </s> on <number> may <year> , an expedition of wales-norman people knight , with an army of about <number> men , landed at bannow in present-day county wexford . it wa led by richard de clare , <number> earl of pembroke , known a 'strongbow ' owing to his prowess a an archer . the invasion , which coincided with a period of renewed norman expansion , wa at the invitation of diarmait mac murchada , king of leinster . </s> in <year> , mac murrough had fled to anjou , france , following a war involving tighearnn ua ruairc , of breifne , and sought the assistance of the angevin empire king king henry ii of england , in recapturing his kingdom . in <year> , henry arrived in ireland in order to review the general progress of the expedition . he wanted to re-exert royal authority over the invasion which wa expanding beyond his control . henry successfully re-imposed his authority over strongbow and the cambro-norman warlord and persuaded many of the irish king to accept him a their overlord , an arrangement confirmed in the <year> treaty of windsor <year> . </s> the invasion wa legitimised by the provision of the papal bull laudabiliter , issued by an englishman , pope adrian iv , in <year> . the bull encouraged henry to take control in ireland in order to oversee the financial and administrative reorganisation of the celtic church and it integration into the roman church system . some restructuring had already begun at the ecclesiastical level following the synod of kells in <year> . there ha been significant controversy regarding the authenticity of laudabiliter , and there is no general agreement a to whether the bull wa genuine or a forgery . </s> in <year> , pope pope alexander iii further encouraged henry to advance the integration of the irish church with rome . henry wa authorised to impose a tithe of one penny per hearth a an annual contribution . this church levy , called peter 's penny , is extant in ireland a a voluntary donation . in turn , henry accepted the title of lord of ireland which henry conferred on his younger son , john lackland , in <year> . this defined the irish state a the lordship of ireland . when henry 's successor died unexpectedly in <year> , john of england inherited the crown of england and retained the lordship of ireland . </s> over the century that followed , norman feudal law gradually replaced the gaelic brehon law so that by the late <number> century the hiberno-norman norman-irish had established a feudal system throughout much of ireland . norman settlement were characterised by the establishment of barony , manor , town and the seed of the modern county system . a version of the magna carta ( the great charter of ireland ) , substituting dublin for london and the irish church for , the english church at the time , the catholic church , wa published in <year> and the parliament of ireland wa founded in <year> . </s> from the mid-14th century , after the black death , norman settlement in ireland went into a period of decline . the norman ruler and the gaelic irish elite intermarried and the area under norman rule became gaelicisation . in some part , a hybrid hiberno-norman culture emerged . in response , the parliament of ireland # middle age passed the statute of kilkenny in <year> . these were a set of law designed to prevent the assimilation of the norman into irish society by requiring english subject in ireland to speak english , follow english custom and abide by english law . </s> by the end of the <number> century , central english authority in ireland had all but disappeared , and a renewed irish culture and language , albeit with norman influence , wa dominant again . english crown control remained relatively unshaken in an amorphous foothold around dublin known a the pale , and under the provision of poynings ' law ( on certification of act ) poynings ' law of <year> , the irish parliamentary legislation wa subject to the approval of the english privy council . </s> <section_title_start> the kingdom of ireland <section_title_end> </s> the title of king of ireland wa re-created in <year> by henry viii , the then king of england , of the tudor dynasty . english rule wa reinforced and expanded in ireland during the latter part of the <number> century , leading to the tudor conquest of ireland . a near-complete conquest wa achieved by the turn of the <number> century , following the nine year ' war ( ireland ) nine year ' war and the flight of the earl . </s> this control wa consolidated during the war and conflict of the <number> century , including the english and scottish colonisation in the plantation of ireland , the war of the three kingdom and the williamite war in ireland . irish loss during the war of the three kingdom ( which , in ireland , included the irish confederacy and the cromwellian conquest of ireland ) are estimated to include <number> battlefield casualty . <number> civilian are estimated to have died a a result of a combination of war-related famine , displacement , guerrilla activity and pestilence throughout the war . a further <number> were sent into indentured servitude in the west indie . physician-general william petty estimated that <number> catholic irish and <number> protestant settler died , and <number> people were transported , a a result of the war . if a prewar population of <number> million is assumed , this would mean that the population wa reduced by almost half . </s> the religious struggle of the <number> century left a deep sectarian division in ireland . religious allegiance now determined the perception in law of loyalty to the irish king and parliament . after the passing of test act # <year> act , and the victory of the force of the dual monarchy of william iii of england and mary ii of england over the jacobitism , roman catholic and nonconforming protestant dissenter were barred from sitting a member in the parliament of ireland . under the emerging penal law ( ireland ) , irish roman catholic and dissenter were increasingly deprived of various and sundry civil right even to the ownership of hereditary property . additional regressive punitive legislation followed in <year> , <year> and <year> . this completed a comprehensive systemic effort to materially disadvantage roman catholic and protestant dissenter , while enriching a new ruling class of anglican conformist . the new anglo-irish ruling class became known a the protestant ascendancy . </s> the `` irish famine ( <year> <number> ) # cause `` struck ireland and the rest of europe between december <year> and september <year> , after a decade of relatively mild winter . the winter destroyed stored crop of potato and other staple , and the poor summer severely damaged harvest . this resulted in the irish famine ( <year> <number> ) . an estimated <number> people ( about one in eight of the population ) died from the ensuing pestilence and disease . the irish government halted export of corn and kept the army in quarter but did little more . local gentry and charitable organisation provided relief but could do little to prevent the ensuing mortality . </s> in the aftermath of the famine , an increase in industrial production and a surge in trade brought a succession of construction boom . the population soared in the latter part of this century and the georgian architecture ireland wa built . in <year> , poynings ' law ( on certification of act ) poynings ' law wa repealed , giving ireland legislative independence from great britain for the first time since <year> . the british government , however , still retained the right to nominate the government of ireland without the consent of the irish parliament . </s> <section_title_start> union with great britain <section_title_end> </s> in <year> , member of the protestant dissenter tradition ( mainly presbyterianism ) made common cause with roman catholic in a republican rebellion inspired and led by the society of united irishman , with the aim of creating an independent ireland . despite assistance from france the irish rebellion of <year> wa put down by british and irish government and yeomanry force . in <year> , the british and irish parliament both passed act of union <year> that , with effect from <number> january <year> , merged the kingdom of ireland and the kingdom of great britain to create a united kingdom of great britain and ireland . </s> the passage of the act in the irish parliament wa ultimately achieved with substantial majority , having failed on the first attempt in <year> . according to contemporary document and historical analysis , this wa achieved through a considerable degree of bribery , with funding provided by the british secret service office , and the awarding of peerage , place and honour to secure vote . thus , the parliament in ireland wa abolished and replaced by a parliament of the united kingdom in london , though resistance remained , a evidenced by robert emmet 's failed irish rebellion of <year> . </s> aside from the development of the linen industry , ireland wa largely passed over by the industrial revolution , partly because it lacked coal and iron resource and partly because of the impact of the sudden union with the structurally superior economy of england , which saw ireland a a source of agricultural produce and capital . </s> the great famine ( ireland ) of <year> <number> devastated ireland , a in those year ireland 's population fell by one-third . more than one million people died from starvation and disease , with an additional million people emigrating during the famine , mostly to the united state and canada . in the century that followed , an economic depression caused by the famine resulted in a further million people emigrating . by the end of the decade , half of all immigration to the united state wa from ireland . the period of civil unrest that followed until the end of the <number> century is referred to a the land war . mass emigration became deeply entrenched and the population continued to decline until the mid-20th century . immediately prior to the famine the population wa recorded a <number> million by the united kingdom census , <year> . the population ha never returned to this level since . the population continued to fall until <year> ; county leitrim wa the final irish county to record a population increase post-famine , in <year> . </s> the <number> and early <number> century saw the rise of modern irish nationalism , primarily among the roman catholic population . the pre-eminent irish political figure after the union wa daniel o'connell . he wa elected a member of parliament for ennis ( uk parliament constituency ) in a surprise result and despite being unable to take his seat the test act . o'connell spearheaded a vigorous campaign that wa taken up by the prime minister , the irish-born soldier and statesman , the arthur wellesley , <number> duke of wellington . steering the roman catholic relief act <year> through parliament , aided by future prime minister robert peel , wellington prevailed upon a reluctant george iv of the united kingdom to sign the bill and proclaim it into law . george iii of the united kingdom george 's father had opposed the plan of the earlier prime minister , william pitt the younger , to introduce such a bill following the union of <year> , fearing catholic emancipation to be in conflict with the act of settlement <year> . </s> daniel o'connell led a subsequent campaign , for the repeal of the act of union , which failed . later in the century , charles stewart parnell and others campaigned for autonomy within the union , or `` irish home rule bill `` . unionist , especially those located in ulster , were strongly opposed to home rule , which they thought would be dominated by catholic interest . after several attempt to pas a home rule bill through parliament , it looked certain that one would finally pas in <year> . to prevent this from happening , the ulster volunteer were formed in <year> under the leadership of edward carson . </s> their formation wa followed in <year> by the establishment of the irish volunteer , whose aim wa to ensure that the third home rule act wa passed . the act wa passed but with the `` temporary `` exclusion of the six county of ulster that would become northern ireland . before it could be implemented , however , the act wa suspended for the duration of the world war i . the irish volunteer split into two group . the majority , approximately <number> in number , under john redmond , took the name national volunteer and supported ireland and world war i in the war . a minority , approximately <number> , retained the irish volunteer ' name and opposed ireland 's involvement in the war . </s> the easter rising of <year> wa carried out by the latter group together with a smaller socialist militia , the irish citizen army . the british response , executing fifteen leader of the rising over a period of ten day and imprisoning or interning more than a thousand people , turned the mood of the country in favour of the rebel . support for physical force irish republicanism further due to the ongoing war in europe , a well a the conscription crisis of <year> . </s> the pro-independence republican party , sinn fin , received overwhelming endorsement in the <year> irish general election , and in <year> proclaimed an irish republic , setting up it own parliament ( first dil ) and government . simultaneously the volunteer , which became known a the irish republican army ( ira ) , launched a irish war of independence three-year guerrilla war , which ended in a truce in july <year> ( although violence continued until june <year> , mostly in northern ireland ) . </s> <section_title_start> partition <section_title_end> </s> in december <year> , the anglo-irish treaty wa concluded between the british government and representative of the second dil . it gave ireland complete independence in it home affair and practical independence for foreign policy , but an opt-out clause allowed northern ireland to remain within the united kingdom , which ( a expected ) it immediately exercised . additionally , member of the third dil were required to swear oath of allegiance ( ireland ) and make a statement of faithfulness to the king . disagreement over these provision led to a split in the nationalist movement and a subsequent irish civil war between the new government of the irish free state and those opposed to the treaty , led by amon de valera . the civil war officially ended in may <year> when de valera issued a cease-fire order . </s> <section_title_start> independence <section_title_end> </s> during it first decade , the newly formed irish free state wa governed by the victor of the civil war . when de valera achieved power , he took advantage of the statute of westminster <year> and edward viii abdication crisis to build upon inroad to greater sovereignty made by the previous government . the oath wa abolished and in <year> a new constitution wa adopted . this completed a process of gradual separation from the british empire that government had pursued since independence . however , it wa not until <year> that the state wa declared , officially , to be the republic of ireland . </s> irish neutrality during the emergency ( ireland ) , but offered irish neutrality during world war ii , particularly in the potential defence of northern ireland . despite their country 's neutrality , approximately <number> volunteer from independent ireland joined the british force during the war , four being awarded victoria cross . </s> the abwehr wa also active in ireland . it operation ended in september <year> when garda sochna made arrest based on surveillance carried out on the key diplomatic legation in dublin . to the authority , counterintelligence wa a fundamental line of defence . with a regular army of only slightly over seven thousand men at the start of the war , and with limited supply of modern weapon , the state would have had great difficulty in defending itself from invasion from either side in the conflict . </s> large-scale emigration marked most of the post-wwii period ( particularly during the <year> and <year> ) , but beginning in <year> the economy improved , and the <year> saw the beginning of substantial economic growth . this period of growth became known a the celtic tiger . the republic 's real gdp grew by an average of <number> per annum between <year> and <year> , in which year the republic joined the euro . in <year> , it wa the sixth-richest country in the world in term of gdp per caput . historian r. f. foster ( historian ) r. f. foster argues the cause wa a combination of a new sense of initiative and the entry of american corporation . he concludes the chief factor were low taxation , pro-business regulatory policy , and a young , tech-savvy workforce . for many multinationals , the decision to do business in ireland wa made easier still by generous incentive from the ida ireland . in addition european union membership wa helpful , giving the country lucrative access to market that it had previously reached only through the united kingdom , and pumping huge subsidy and investment capital into the irish economy . </s> modernisation brought secularisation in it wake . the traditionally high level of religiosity have sharply declined . foster point to three factor : irish feminism , largely imported from america with liberal stance on contraception , abortion , and divorce undermined the authority of bishop and priest . second , the mishandling of the pedophile scandal humiliated the church , whose bishop seemed le concerned with the victim and more concerned with covering up for errant priest . third , prosperity brought hedonism and materialism that undercut the ideal of saintly poverty . </s> the post-2008 irish economic downturn that began in <year> dramatically ended this period of boom . gdp fell by <number> in <year> and by <number> in <year> , the worst year since record began ( although earnings by foreign-owned business continued to grow ) . the state ha since experienced deep recession , with unemployment , which doubled during <year> , remaining above <number> in <year> . </s> <section_title_start> northern ireland <section_title_end> </s> northern ireland resulted from the division of the united kingdom by the government of ireland act <year> , and until <year> wa a self-governing jurisdiction within the united kingdom with it own parliament and prime minister . northern ireland , a part of the united kingdom , wa not neutral during the second world war , and belfast blitz in <year> . conscription wa not extended to northern ireland , and roughly an equal number volunteered from northern ireland a volunteered from the south . </s> although northern ireland wa largely spared the strife of the civil war , in decade that followed partition there were sporadic episode of inter-communal violence . nationalist , mainly roman catholic , wanted to unite ireland a an independent republic , whereas unionist , mainly protestant , wanted northern ireland to remain in the united kingdom . the protestant and catholic community in northern ireland voted largely along sectarian line , meaning that the government of northern ireland ( elected by plurality electoral system `` first-past-the-post `` from <year> ) wa controlled by the ulster unionist party . over time , the minority catholic community felt increasingly alienated with further disaffection fuelled by practice such a gerrymandering and discrimination in housing and employment . </s> in the late <year> , nationalist grievance were aired publicly in mass civil right protest , which were often confronted by ulster loyalism counter-protests . the government 's reaction to confrontation wa seen to be one-sided and heavy-handed in favour of unionist . law and order broke down a unrest and inter-communal violence increased . the northern ireland government requested the british army to aid the police and protect the irish nationalist population . in <year> , the paramilitary provisional irish republican army , which favoured the creation of a united ireland , emerged from a split in the irish republican army ( <year> <number> ) and began a campaign against what it called the `` british occupation of the six county `` . </s> other group , on both the unionist side and the nationalist side , participated in violence and a period known a the trouble began . over <number> death resulted over the subsequent three decade of conflict . owing to the civil unrest during the trouble , the british government suspended home rule in <year> and imposed direct rule over northern ireland . there were several unsuccessful attempt to end the trouble politically , such a the sunningdale agreement of <year> . in <year> , following a ceasefire by the provisional ira and multi-party talk , the good friday agreement wa concluded a a treaty between the british and irish government , annexing the text agreed in the multi-party talk . </s> the substance of the agreement ( formally referred to a the belfast agreement ) wa later endorsed by referendum in both part of ireland . the agreement restored self-government to northern ireland on the basis of power-sharing in a regional northern ireland executive drawn from the major party in a new northern ireland assembly , with entrenched protection for the two main community . the executive is jointly headed by a first minister and deputy first minister drawn from the unionist and nationalist party . violence had decreased greatly after the provisional ira and loyalist ceasefires in <year> and in <year> the provisional ira announced the end of it armed campaign and an independent international commission on decommissioning supervised it disarmament and that of other nationalist and unionist paramilitary organisation . </s> the assembly and power-sharing executive were suspended several time but were restored again in <year> . in that year the british government officially ended it military support of the police in northern ireland ( operation banner ) and began withdrawing troop . </s> on <number> june <year> , northern ireland 's deputy first minister and former ira commander , martin mcguinness , shook hand with queen elizabeth ii in belfast , symbolising reconciliation between the two side . </s> <section_title_start> politics <section_title_end> </s> the island is divided between the republic of ireland , an independent sovereign state , and northern ireland ( a constituent country of the united kingdom ) . they share an irish border and both are part of the common travel area . </s> the republic of ireland is a member of the european union while the united kingdom is a former member , having both acceded to it precursor entity , the european economic community [ eec ] , in <year> , and a a consequence there is internal market free movement of people , good , service and capital across the border . </s> <section_title_start> republic of ireland <section_title_end> </s> the republic of ireland is a parliamentary democracy based on the british model , with a constitution of ireland and a popularly elected president who ha mostly ceremonial power . the government of ireland is headed by a prime minister , the taoiseach , who is appointed by the president of ireland on the nomination of the lower house of parliament , the dil ireann . member of the government are chosen from both the dil and the upper house of parliament , the seanad ireann . it capital is dublin . </s> the republic today rank amongst the wealthiest country in the world in term of gdp per caput and in <year> wa ranked the sixth most developed nation in the world by the united nation ' human development index . a period of rapid economic expansion from <year> onwards became known a the celtic tiger period , wa brought to an end in <year> with an unprecedented post-2008 irish economic downturn and an economic depression in <year> . </s> <section_title_start> northern ireland <section_title_end> </s> northern ireland is a part of the united kingdom with a local northern ireland executive and northern ireland assembly which exercise devolved power . the executive is jointly headed by the first and deputy first minister , with the ministry being allocated in proportion with each party 's representation in the assembly . it capital is belfast . </s> ultimately political power is held by the uk government , from which northern ireland ha gone through intermittent period of direct rule during which devolved power have been suspended . northern ireland elect <number> of the uk house of common of the united kingdom ' <number> mp . the northern ireland secretary is a cabinet-level post in the british government . </s> along with england and wale and with scotland , northern ireland form one of the three separate legal jurisdiction of the uk , all of which share the supreme court of the united kingdom a their court of final appeal . </s> <section_title_start> all-island institutions <section_title_end> </s> a part of the good friday agreement , the british and irish government agreed on the creation of all-island institution and area of cooperation . the north/south ministerial council is an institution through which minister from the government of ireland and the northern ireland executive agree all-island policy . at least six of these policy area must have an associated all-island `` implementation body , `` and at least six others must be implemented separately in each jurisdiction . the implementation body are : waterway ireland , the food safety promotion board , intertradeireland , the special european union programme body , the north/south language body and the commissioner of irish light foyle , carlingford and irish light commission . </s> the britishirish intergovernmental conference provides for co-operation between the government of ireland and the government of the united kingdom on all matter of mutual interest , especially northern ireland . in light of the republic 's particular interest in the governance of northern ireland , `` regular and frequent `` meeting co-chaired by the roi minister for foreign affair and the uk secretary of state for northern ireland , dealing with non-devolved matter to do with northern ireland and non-devolved all-ireland issue , are required to take place under the establishing treaty . </s> the north/south inter-parliamentary association is a joint parliamentary forum for the island of ireland . it ha no formal power but operates a a forum for discussing matter of common concern between the respective legislature . </s> <section_title_start> economy <section_title_end> </s> despite the two jurisdiction using two distinct currency ( the euro and pound sterling ) , a growing amount of commercial activity is carried out for the creation of an `` all-ireland economy `` to take advantage of economy of scale and boost competitiveness . </s> there are two multi-city region on the island of ireland : </s> # dublin-belfast ireland ) in the republic of ireland . </s> dublin is the most heavily touristed region and home to several of the most popular attraction such a the guinness storehouse and book of kells . the west <section_title_start> energy <section_title_end> </s> ireland ha an ancient industry based on peat ( known locally a `` turf `` ) a a source of energy for home fire . a form of biomass energy , this source of heat is still widely used in rural area . however , because of the ecological importance of peatlands in storing carbon and their rarity , the eu is attempting to protect this habitat by fining ireland for digging up peat . in city , heat is generally supplied by natural gas or [ oil ] , although some urban supplier distribute sod of turf a `` smokeless fuel `` for domestic use . </s> the island operates a a single market for electricity . for much of their existence , electricity network in the republic of ireland and northern ireland were entirely separate . both network were designed and constructed independently post-partition . however , they are now connected with three interlinks and also connected through great britain to mainland europe . the situation in northern ireland is complicated by the issue of private company not supplying northern ireland electricity with enough power . in the republic of ireland , the esb group ha failed to modernise it power station , and the availability of power plant ha recently averaged only <number> , one of the worst such rate in western europe . eirgrid ha started building a high-voltage direct current transmission line between ireland and great britain with a capacity of <number> mw , about <number> of ireland 's peak demand . </s> a with electricity , the natural gas distribution network is also now all-island , with a pipeline linking gormanston , county meath , and ballyclare , county antrim . most of ireland 's gas come through interconnectors between twynholm in scotland and ballylumford power station , county antrim and loughshinny , county dublin . supply come from the corrib gas field , off the coast of county mayo , with a decreasing supply coming from the kinsale gas field off the county cork coast . the county mayo field face some localised opposition over corrib gas controversy to refine the gas onshore . </s> the republic ha a strong commitment to renewable energy and rank a one of the top <number> market for clean technology clean-technology investment in the <year> global green economy index . research and development in renewable energy ( such a wind power ) ha increased since <year> . large list of wind farm in the republic of ireland in cork , donegal , mayo and antrim . the construction of wind farm ha in some case been delayed by opposition from local community , some of whom regard the wind turbine a unsightly . the republic is hindered by an ageing network that wa not designed to handle the varying availability of power that come from wind farm . the esb 's turlough hill facility is the only power-storage facility in the state . </s> <section_title_start> economic history <section_title_end> </s> prior to partition in <year> , ireland had a long history a an economic colony - first of the norse ( <number> to <number> century ce ) , and later of england . though the climate and soil favoured certain form of agriculture , trade barrier frequently hobbled it development . repeated invasion and plantation of ireland `` plantation `` disrupted land tenure land-ownership , and irish rebellion ( disambiguation ) also contributed to repeated phase of penal transportation and of irish emigrant . </s> salient event in the economic history of ireland include : </s> * <number> and <number> century : confiscation and redistribution of land in the plantation of ireland </s> * <year> : great famine ( ireland ) occasioned depopulation and mass emigration . </s> * <year> : westminster 's repeal of the corn law disrupted irish agriculture . </s> <section_title_start> geography <section_title_end> </s> ireland is located in the north-west europe north-west of europe , between latitude <number> parallel north <number> and <number> parallel north <number> n , and longitude <number> meridian west <number> and <number> meridian west <number> w. it is separated from great britain by the irish sea and the north channel ( great britain and ireland ) , which ha a width of at it narrowest point . to the west is the northern atlantic ocean and to the south is the celtic sea , which lie between ireland and brittany , in france . ireland ha a total area of , of which the republic of ireland occupies <number> percent . ireland and great britain , together with many nearby smaller island , are known collectively a the british isle . a british isle naming dispute in relation to ireland , the alternate term britain and ireland is often used a a neutral term for the island . </s> a ring of coastal mountain surround low plain at the centre of the island . the highest of these is carrauntoohil ( corrn tuathail ) in county kerry , which rise to above sea level . the most arable land lie in the province of leinster . western area can be mountainous and rocky with green panoramic vista . river shannon , the island 's longest river at long , rise in county cavan in the north west and flow through limerick in the mid west . </s> <section_title_start> geology <section_title_end> </s> the island consists of varied geologic province . in the west , around county galway and county donegal , is a medium to high grade metamorphic and igneous complex of caledonides affinity , similar to the scottish highland . across southeast ulster and extending southwest to longford and south to navan is a province of ordovician and silurian rock , with similarity to the southern upland province of scotland . further south , along the county wexford coastline , is an area of granite intrusion into more ordovician and silurian rock , like that found in wale . </s> in the southwest , around bantry bay and the mountain of macgillycuddy 's reek , is an area of substantially deformed , lightly metamorphic rock devonian-aged rock . this partial ring of `` hard rock `` geology is covered by a blanket of carboniferous limestone over the centre of the country , giving rise to a comparatively fertile and lush landscape . the west-coast district of the burren around lisdoonvarna ha well-developed karst feature . significant stratiform lead-zinc mineralisation is found in the limestone around silvermines and tynagh . </s> hydrocarbon exploration is ongoing following the first major find at the kinsale head gas field off cork ( city ) in the mid-1970s . in <year> , economically significant find of natural gas were made in the corrib gas field off the county mayo coast . this ha increased activity off the west coast in parallel with the `` north sea oil # west of shetland `` step-out development from the north sea oil . in <year> , the helvick oil field wa discovered , which wa estimated to contain over of oil . </s> file : dunluce castle.jpg dunluce castle , county antrim </s> file : benbulbenmount.jpg benbulbin , county sligo </s> file : twelve pins.jpg connemara , county galway </s> file : glendalough.jpg glendalough , county wicklow </s> file : lady view ( <year> ) .jpg lady view , county kerry </s> file : loch an ghleanna bhig ( glenbeg lough ) - geograph.org.uk - <year> <number>jpg glenbeg lough , county cork </s> <section_title_start> climate <section_title_end> </s> the island 's lush vegetation , a product of it mild climate and frequent rainfall , earns it the sobriquet the emerald isle . overall , ireland ha a mild but changeable oceanic climate with few extreme . the climate is typically insular and is temperate climate , avoiding the extreme in temperature of many other area in the world at similar latitude . this is a result of the moderating moist wind which ordinarily prevail from the southwestern atlantic . </s> precipitation fall throughout the year but is light overall , particularly in the east . the west tends to be wetter on average and prone to atlantic storm , especially in the late autumn and winter month . these occasionally bring destructive wind and higher total rainfall to these area , a well a sometimes snow and hail . the region of north county galway and east county mayo have the highest incident of recorded lightning annually for the island , with lightning occurring approximately five to ten day per year in these area . munster , in the south , record the least snow whereas ulster , in the north , record the most . </s> inland area are warmer in summer and colder in winter . usually around <number> day of the year are below freezing at inland weather station , compared to <number> day at coastal station . ireland is sometimes affected by heatwaves , most recently in <year> , <year> european heat wave , <year> european heat wave # ireland , <year> and <year> british isle heat wave . in common with the rest of europe , ireland experienced unusually cold weather during winter of <year> <number> in great britain and ireland the winter of <year> . temperature fell a low a <number> ; c ( <number> ; f ) in county mayo on <number> december and up to a metre ( <number> ; ft ) of snow fell in mountainous area . </s> <section_title_start> flora and fauna <section_title_end> </s> because ireland became isolated from mainland europe by rising sea level before the last glacial period had completely finished , it ha fewer land animal and plant specie than great britain or mainland europe . there are list of mammal of ireland in ireland , and of them only <number> land mammal specie are considered native to ireland . some specie , such a , the red fox , european hedgehog and european badger , are very common , whereas others , like the mountain hare , red deer and pine marten are le so . aquatic wildlife , such a specie of sea turtle , shark , seal , whale , and dolphin , are common off the coast . about <number> specie of bird have been recorded in ireland . many of these are migratory , including the barn swallow . </s> several different habitat type are found in ireland , including farmland , open woodland , temperate broadleaf and mixed forest , conifer plantation , peat bog and a variety of coastal habitat . however , agriculture drive current land use pattern in ireland , limiting natural habitat preserve , particularly for larger wild mammal with greater territorial need . with no large apex predator in ireland other than human and dog , such population of animal a semi-wild deer that can not be controlled by smaller predator , such a the fox , are controlled by annual culling . </s> there are no snake in ireland , and only one specie of reptile ( the viviparous lizard ) is native to the island . extinct specie include the irish elk , the great auk , brown bear and the wolf in ireland . some previously extinct bird , such a the golden eagle , have been reintroduced after decade of local extinction . </s> ireland is now one of the least forested country in europe . until the end of the middle age , ireland wa heavily forested with native tree such a oak , fraxinus excelsior , corylus avellana , birch , alnus glutinosa , willow , populus tremula , sorbus aucuparia , taxus baccata and scot pine . only about <number> of ireland today is woodland ; most of this is non-native conifer plantation , and only <number> is native woodland . in europe , the average woodland cover is over <number> . in the republic , about is owned by the state , mainly by the forestry service coillte . remnant of native forest can be found scattered around the island , in particular in the killarney national park . </s> much of the land is now covered with pasture and there are many specie of wild-flower . gorse ( ulex europaeus ) , a wild furze , is commonly found growing in the upland and fern are plentiful in the more moist region , especially in the western part . it is home to hundred of plant specie , some of them unique to the island , and ha been `` invaded `` by some grass , such a spartina anglica . </s> the algal and seaweed flora is that of the cold-temperate variety . the total number of specie is <number> the island ha been invaded by some algae , some of which are now well established . </s> because of it mild climate , many specie , including subtropics sub-tropical specie such a arecaceae , are grown in ireland . phytogeography , ireland belongs to the atlantic european province of the circumboreal region within the boreal kingdom . the island can be subdivided into two ecoregions : the celtic broadleaf forest and north atlantic moist mixed forest . </s> <section_title_start> impact of agriculture <section_title_end> </s> the long history of agricultural production , coupled with modern intensive agricultural method such a pesticide and fertiliser use and runoff from contaminant into stream , river and lake , ha placed pressure on biodiversity in ireland . a land of green field for crop cultivation and cattle rearing limit the space available for the establishment of native wild specie . hedgerow , however , traditionally used for maintaining and demarcating land boundary , act a a refuge for native wild flora . this ecosystem stretch across the countryside and act a a network of connection to preserve remnant of the ecosystem that once covered the island . subsidy under the common agricultural policy , which supported agricultural practice that preserved hedgerow environment , are undergoing reform . the common agricultural policy had in the past subsidised potentially destructive agricultural practice , for example by emphasising production without placing limit on indiscriminate use of fertiliser and pesticide ; but reform have gradually decoupled subsidy from production level and introduced environmental and other requirement . <number> of ireland 's greenhouse gas emission are correlated to agriculture.forested area typically consist of monoculture plantation of non-native specie , which may result in habitat that are not suitable for supporting native specie of invertebrate . natural area require fencing to prevent over-grazing by deer of ireland and sheep that roam over uncultivated area . grazing in this manner is one of the main factor preventing the natural regeneration of forest across many region of the country . </s> <section_title_start> demographics <section_title_end> </s> people have lived in ireland for over <number> year . early historical and genealogical record note the existence of major group such a the cruthin , corcu logde , dl riata , dirine , deirgtine , delbhna , rainn , laigin , ulaid . later major group included the connachta , ciannachta , eganachta . smaller group included the aithechthatha ( see attacotti ) , clraighe , carraige , conmaicne , dartraighe , disi , ile , fir bolg , fortuatha , gailenga , gamanraige , mairtine , mscraige , partraige , soghain , uaithni , u maine , u liathin . many survived into late medieval time , others vanished a they became politically unimportant . over the past <number> year , viking , norman , welsh people , fleming , scottish people , english people , african , eastern european and south american have all added to the population and have had significant influence on irish culture . </s> the population of ireland rose rapidly from the <number> century until the mid-19th century , interrupted briefly by the irish famine ( <year> <number> ) famine of <year> <number> , which killed roughly two fifth of the island 's population . the population rebounded and multiplied over the next century , but the great famine ( ireland ) of the <year> caused one million death and forced over one million more to emigrate in it immediate wake . over the following century , the population wa reduced by over half , at a time when the general trend in european country wa for population to rise by an average of three-fold . </s> ireland 's largest religious group is christianity . the largest denomination is roman catholicism , representing over <number> for the island ( and about <number> of the republic of ireland ) . most of the rest of the population adhere to one of the various protestant denomination ( about <number> of northern ireland ) . the largest is the anglicanism church of ireland . the islam in ireland is growing in ireland , mostly through increased immigration , with a <number> increase in the republic between the <year> and <year> census . the island ha a small history of the jew in ireland . about <number> of the republic 's population and about <number> of the northern ireland population describe themselves a of no religion . in a <year> survey conducted on behalf of the irish time , <number> of respondent said they went to a religious service more than once per week . </s> <section_title_start> divisions and settlements <section_title_end> </s> traditionally , ireland is subdivided into province of ireland : connacht ( west ) , leinster ( east ) , munster ( south ) , and ulster ( north ) . in a system that developed between the <number> and <number> century , ireland ha county of ireland . twenty-six of these county are in the republic of ireland , and county of northern ireland . the six county that constitute northern ireland are all in the province of ulster ( which ha nine county in total ) . a such , ulster is often used a a synonym for northern ireland , although the two are not coterminous.in the republic of ireland , county form the basis of the system of local government . county county dublin , county cork , county limerick , county galway , county waterford and county tipperary have been broken up into smaller administrative area . however , they are still treated a county for cultural and some official purpose , for example , postal address and by the ordnance survey ireland . county in northern ireland are local government in northern ireland for local governmental purpose , but , a in the republic , their traditional boundary are still used for informal purpose such a sport league and in cultural or tourism context . </s> city status in ireland is decided by legislation or royal charter . dublin , with over <number> million resident in the greater dublin area , is the largest city on the island . belfast , with <number> resident , is the largest city in northern ireland . city status doe not directly equate with population size . for example , armagh , with <number> is the seat of the church of ireland and the roman catholic primate of all ireland and wa re-granted ireland , kilkenny , seat of the butler dynasty , while no longer a city for administrative purpose ( since the <year> local government act <year> ) , is entitled by law to continue to use the description . </s> <section_title_start> migration <section_title_end> </s> the population of ireland collapsed dramatically during the second half of the <number> century . a population of over <number> million in <year> wa reduced to slightly more than <number> million by <year> . in part , the fall in population wa caused by death from the great famine ( ireland ) of <year> to <year> , which took about <number> million life . however , by far the greater cause of population decline wa the dire economic state of the country which led to an entrenched culture of emigration lasting until the <number> century . </s> emigration from ireland in the <number> century contributed to the population of england , the united state , canada and australia , in all of which a large irish diaspora life . , <number> million canadian , or <number> of the population , were of irish descent , while around one-third of the australian population had an element of irish descent . , there were <number> million irish-americans and <number> million american who claimed irish ancestry . </s> with growing prosperity since the last decade of the <number> century , ireland became a destination for immigrant . since the european union expanded to include poland in <year> , polish people have made up the largest number of immigrant ( over <number> ) from central europe . there ha also been significant immigration from lithuania , czech republic and latvia . </s> the republic of ireland in particular ha seen large-scale immigration , with <number> foreign national a of <year> , about <number> of the population . a quarter of birth ( <number> percent ) in <year> were to mother born outside ireland . up to <number> eastern and central european migrant worker left ireland in response to the irish financial crisis . </s> <section_title_start> languages <section_title_end> </s> the two official language of the republic of ireland are irish and english . each language ha produced noteworthy literature . irish , though now only the language of a minority , wa the vernacular of the irish people for thousand of year and wa possibly introduced during the iron age . it began to be written down after christianisation in the <number> century and spread to scotland and the isle of man , where it evolved into the scottish gaelic and manx language language respectively . </s> the irish language ha a vast treasury of written text from many century and is divided by linguist into old irish from the <number> to <number> century , middle irish from the <number> to <number> century , early modern irish until the <number> century , and the modern irish spoken today . it remained the dominant language of ireland for most of those period , having influence from latin language , old norse , anglo-norman language and english . it declined under british rule but remained the majority tongue until the early <number> century , and since then ha been a minority language . </s> the gaelic revival of the early <number> century ha had a long-term influence . irish is taught in mainstream irish school a a compulsory subject , but teaching method have been criticised for their ineffectiveness , with the lack of level of ability after , typically , fourteen year of instruction cited . </s> there is now a network of urban irish speaker in both the republic and northern ireland , especially in dublin and belfast , with the child of such irish speaker sometimes attending irish-medium school ( gaelscoil gaelscoileanna ) . it ha been argued that they tend to be more highly educated than monolingual english speaker . recent research suggests that urban irish is developing in a direction of it own , both in pronunciation and grammar . </s> traditional rural irish-speaking area , known collectively a the gaeltacht , are in linguistic decline . the main gaeltacht area are in the west , south-west and north-west . they are to be found in donegal , mayo , galway , western cork and kerry with smaller gaeltacht area near dungarvan in waterford , navan in meath . </s> hiberno-english wa first introduced during the norman invasion . it wa spoken by a few peasant and merchant brought over from england , and wa largely replaced by irish before the tudor conquest of ireland . it wa introduced a the official language with the tudor and cromwellian conquest . the ulster plantation gave it a permanent foothold in ulster , and it remained the official and upper-class language elsewhere , the irish-speaking chieftain and nobility having been deposed . language shift during the <number> century replaced irish with english a the first language for a vast majority of the population . </s> le than <number> of the population of the republic of ireland today speak irish regularly outside of the education system and <number> of those over <number> year are classified a `` irish speaker `` . in northern ireland , english is the de facto official language , but official recognition is afforded to irish , including specific protective measure under part iii of the european charter for regional or minority language . a lesser status ( including recognition under part ii of the charter ) is given to ulster scot dialect , which are spoken by roughly <number> of northern ireland resident , and also spoken by some in the republic of ireland . since the <year> with the increase in immigration , many more language have been introduced , particularly deriving from asia and eastern europe . </s> shelta language , the language of the nomadic irish traveller is native to ireland . </s> <section_title_start> culture <section_title_end> </s> ireland 's culture comprises element of the culture of ancient people , later immigrant and broadcast cultural influence ( chiefly gael , anglicisation , americanisation and aspect of broader european culture ) . in broad term , ireland is regarded a one of the celtic nation of europe , alongside scotland , wale , cornwall , isle of man and brittany . this combination of cultural influence is visible in the intricate design termed irish interlace ( visual art ) or celtic knotwork . these can be seen in the ornamentation of medieval religious and secular work . the style is still popular today in jewellery and graphic art , a is the distinctive style of traditional irish music and dance , and ha become indicative of modern `` celtic `` culture in general . </s> religion in ireland ha played a significant role in the cultural life of the island since ancient time ( and since the <number> century plantation of ireland , ha been the focus of political identity and division on the island ) . ireland 's pre-christian heritage fused with the celtic church following the mission of saint patrick in the <number> century . the hiberno-scottish mission , begun by the irish monk saint columba , spread the celtic christianity to pagan anglo-saxon england and the frankish empire . these mission brought written language to an illiterate population of europe during the dark age that followed the fall of rome , earning ireland the sobriquet , `` the island of saint and scholar `` . </s> since the <number> century irish pub worldwide have become outpost of irish culture , especially those with a full range of cultural and gastronomic offering . </s> the republic of ireland 's national theatre is the abbey theatre , which wa founded in <year> , and the national irish-language theatre is an taibhdhearc , which wa established in <year> in galway . playwright such a sen o'casey , brian friel , sebastian barry , conor mcpherson and billy roche are internationally renowned . </s> <section_title_start> arts <section_title_end> </s> <section_title_start> literature <section_title_end> </s> ireland ha made a large contribution to world literature in all it branch , both in irish and english . poetry in irish is among the oldest vernacular literature in europe , with the earliest example dating from the <number> century . </s> irish remained the dominant literary language down to the nineteenth century , despite the spread of english from the seventeenth century on . prominent name from the medieval period and later include gofraidh fionn dlaigh ( fourteenth century ) , dibh bruadair ( seventeenth century ) and aogn rathaille ( eighteenth century ) . eibhln dubh n chonaill ( c. <year> c. <year> ) wa an outstanding poet in the oral tradition . the latter part of the nineteenth century saw a rapid replacement of irish by english . by <year> , however , cultural nationalist had begun the gaelic revival , which saw the beginning of modern literature in irish . this wa to produce a number of notable writer , including mirtn cadhain , mire mhac an tsaoi and others . irish-language publisher such a coiscim and cl iar-chonnacht continue to produce score of title every year . </s> in english , jonathan swift , often called the foremost satirist in the english language , gained fame for work such a gulliver 's travel and a modest proposal . other notable <number>-century writer of irish origin included oliver goldsmith and richard brinsley sheridan , though they spent most of their life in england . the anglo-irish novel came to the fore in the nineteenth century , featuring such writer a charles kickham , william carleton , and ( in collaboration ) edith somerville and violet florence martin . the playwright and poet oscar wilde , noted for his epigram , wa born in ireland . </s> in the <number> century , ireland produced four winner of the nobel prize for literature : george bernard shaw , william butler yeats , samuel beckett and seamus heaney . although not a nobel prize winner , james joyce is widely considered to be one of the most significant writer of the <number> century . joyce 's <year> novel ulysses ( novel ) is considered one of the most important work of modernist literature and his life is celebrated annually on <number> june in dublin a `` bloomsday `` . a comparable writer in irish is mirtn cadhain , whose novel cr na cille is regarded a a modernist masterpiece and ha been translated into several language . </s> modern irish literature is often connected with it rural heritage through english-language writer such a john mcgahern and seamus heaney and irish-language writer such a mirtn direin and others from the gaeltacht . </s> <section_title_start> music <section_title_end> </s> music ha been in evidence in ireland since prehistoric time . although in the early middle age the church wa `` quite unlike it counterpart in continental europe `` , there wa considerable interchange between monastic settlement in ireland and the rest of europe that contributed to what is known a gregorian chant . outside religious establishment , musical genre in early gaelic ireland are referred to a a triad of weeping music ( goltraige ) , laughing music ( geantraige ) and sleeping music ( suantraige ) . vocal and instrumental music ( e.g . for the harp , pipe , and various string instrument ) wa transmitted orally , but the irish harp , in particular , wa of such significance that it became ireland 's national symbol . classical music following european model first developed in urban area , in establishment of anglo-irish rule such a dublin castle , st patrick 's cathedral , dublin st patrick 's cathedral and christ church cathedral , dublin a well a the country house of the anglo-irish ascendancy , with the first performance of george frideric handel 's messiah ( handel ) ( <year> ) being among the highlight of the baroque era . in the <number> century , public concert provided access to classical music to all class of society . yet , for political and financial reason ireland ha been too small to provide a living to many musician , so the name of the better-known list of irish classical composer of this time belong to emigrant . </s> irish folk music and dance ha seen a surge in popularity and global coverage since the <year> . in the middle year of the <number> century , a irish society wa modernising , traditional music had fallen out of favour , especially in urban area . however during the <year> , there wa a revival of interest in irish traditional music led by group such a the dubliner , the chieftain , the wolfe tone , the clancy brother , sweeney 's men and individual like sen riada and christy moore . group and musician including horslips , van morrison and thin lizzy incorporated element of irish traditional music into contemporary rock music and , during the <year> and <year> , the distinction between traditional and rock musician became blurred , with many individual regularly crossing over between these style of playing . this trend can be seen more recently in the work of artist like enya , the saw doctor , the corrs , sinad o'connor , clannad ( musical group ) , the cranberry and the pogues among others . </s> <section_title_start> art <section_title_end> </s> the earliest known irish graphic art and sculpture are neolithic carving found at site such a newgrange and is traced through bronze age artefact and the religious carving and illuminated manuscript of the medieval period . during the course of the <number> and <number> century , a strong tradition of painting emerged , including such figure a john butler yeats , william orpen , jack yeats and louis le brocquy . contemporary irish visual artist of note include sean scully , kevin abosch , and alice maher . </s> <section_title_start> science <section_title_end> </s> the irish philosopher and theologian johannes scotus eriugena wa considered one of the leading intellectual of the early middle age . sir ernest henry shackleton , an irish explorer , wa one of the principal figure of antarctic exploration . he , along with his expedition , made the first ascent of mount erebus and the discovery of the approximate location of the south magnetic pole . robert boyle wa a <number>-century natural philosopher , chemist , physicist , inventor and early gentleman scientist . he is largely regarded a one of the founder of modern chemistry and is best known for the formulation of boyle 's law . </s> <number>-century physicist , john tyndall , discovered the tyndall effect . father nicholas joseph callan , professor of natural philosophy in maynooth college , is best known for his invention of the induction coil , transformer and he discovered an early method of galvanisation in the <number> century . </s> other notable irish physicist include ernest walton , winner of the <year> nobel prize in physic . with sir john douglas cockcroft , he wa the first to split the nucleus of the atom by artificial mean and made contribution to the development of a new theory of wave equation . william thomson , or lord kelvin , is the person whom the absolute temperature unit , the kelvin , is named after . sir joseph larmor , a physicist and mathematician , made innovation in the understanding of electricity , dynamic , thermodynamics and the electron theory of matter . his most influential work wa aether and matter , a book on theoretical physic published in <year> . </s> george johnstone stoney introduced the term electron in <year> . john stewart bell wa the originator of bell 's theorem and a paper concerning the discovery of the chiral anomaly bell-jackiw-adler anomaly and wa nominated for a nobel prize . the astronomer jocelyn bell burnell , from lurgan , county armagh , discovered pulsar in <year> . notable mathematician include sir william rowan hamilton , famous for work in hamiltonian mechanic and the invention of quaternion . francis ysidro edgeworth 's contribution of the edgeworth box remains influential in neo-classical microeconomic theory to this day ; while richard cantillon inspired adam smith , among others . john b. cosgrave wa a specialist in number theory and discovered a <year> -digit prime number in <year> and a record composite fermat number in <year> . john lighton synge made progress in different field of science , including mechanic and geometrical method in general relativity . he had mathematician john forbes nash , jr. a one of his student . kathleen lonsdale , born in ireland and most known for her work with x-ray crystallography , became the first female president of the british association for the advancement of science . </s> ireland ha nine university , seven in the republic of ireland and two in northern ireland , including trinity college , dublin and the university college dublin , a well a numerous third-level college and institute and a branch of the open university , the open university in ireland . </s> <section_title_start> sports <section_title_end> </s> gaelic football is the most popular sport in ireland in term of match attendance and community involvement , with about <number> club on the
